Of course this country and every other country needs timber. We need timber for the production of pulp and paper. We need it for construction purposes. We need it as a prime cabinet material and a lesser type of cabinet material. We need timber such as hoop, bunya and kauri pine. This country is facing every month a massive current account deficit which is having a deleterious effect on our economy, the value of our dollar, interest rates and everything else. Yet Australia is a net importer of timber. According to the latest figures I have, in 1982-83 we imported timber to the value of $666,881,000. The Democrats are trying to destroy this industry at a time when we have a massive current account deficit problem and we are importing nearly $700m worth of timber products.

SPEECH.PARA: The timber industry is a major economic factor. This is no more so than in the honourable senator's home State of Tasmania. The honourable senator mentioned jobs. The timber industry and its ancillary industries are the second largest employer in Tasmania. The forest-based industries in Tasmania earn aroung $250m a year. The woodchip industry alone earns about $100m a year. Senator Sanders raved on-or brayed on, if one likes-about a so-called subsidy. The honourable senator got his information from the Centre for Environmental Studies at the University of Tasmania, which really has no economic expertise. In fairness, a proper economic study was carried out in Tasmania. The statement of the Centre for Environmental Studies was looked at and was found to be based on a pretty false premise.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am quoting from the ANU study that has refuted that.

—I am talking about the study undertaken by Dr Bruce Felmingham, an economist in Tasmania. The Centre for Environmental Studies has not answered his queries. He has answered its questions but neither the Centre nor the Australian National University has answered the questions put by him. First of all, the claim of an $8m road usage subsidy is false. The $6m component in the Forestry Commission deficit attributed to the industry cannot be substantiated and, indeed, was not substantiated by the ANU or by the Centre for Environmental Studies. It is acknowledged that there is an interest component in respect of the Forestry Commission. However, that interest was incurred really before the woodchip industry got going. So the claim about the subsidy of $20m is entirely false. Even if it were not, a $250m return is not a bad investment on a $20m subsidy. However, this claim is entirely false.

SPEECH.PARA: Royalties are paid by the industry. Senator Sanders mentioned roads. A road toll is paid to government. An ex gratia payment is made to local government. The foresters maintain many of their own roads. Indeed, both Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd and, I think, Forest Resources are responsible for a road which bypasses Launceston and which is used by trucks involved in the woodchip industry in the Tamar River area north of Launceston. So much for the unsubstantiated allegations of Senator Sanders. I understand that the forestry industry and associated industries in Queensland are worth around $900m per annum and employ about 16,000 people in 800 primary and secondary manufacturing establishments.

As I pointed out, conservation is concerned with using and at the same time preserving for future generations. If one were to listen to the lunatic fringe of the conservation movement-I put Senator Sanders in that category-one would think, as he indicated, that there will be very little rainforest area left in a couple of years time.

In Tasmania 26 per cent of the land area is reserved from logging in national parks, conservation areas, forestry reserves and other crown parks. That has been due to the responsible action of the Tasmanian Government in putting away that area. Recently, on that very subjective program Quantum-I wish that Hansard could pick up the inflection of one's voice-we had the New South Wales Minister for Planning and Environment give gratuitous advice to Queensland, saying that if we do not do what New South Wales has done, there will be no rain- forest left. New South Wales has locked up its total rainforest area of 250,000 hectares. Queensland has locked up three times that much in national parks and forestry reserves that will not be logged-stream sites, scientific areas and the like. There we have Queensland's responsible action in locking up that area. All the New South Wales Minister is telling us is about his own inability to manage his resources. He locks them away so that nobody can get at them. I do not know where he gets his timber from, but it would have to be imported from somewhere else where resources are better managed than in New South Wales, such as from Queensland or Tasmania, or from overseas where we do not know how they are managed.

Queensland has 750,000 hectares locked up in national parks or areas that will not be logged. I suppose one of the most emotional arguments running in Queensland at this time is that of the Daintree, mainly for the fact that a road was put through an area that is in neither a forestry nor a national park reserve. The area was excised when the surrounding area was made a national park. The road was put through for the deliberate purpose of giving access to people up the coast, from Bloomfield to Cape Tribulation. I have put on the record before, but I will do so again, that it saves the people of Bloomfield about a 400-kilometre round trip to Cairns. The road actually runs through 1 1/4 kilometres of prime, pristine, primeval rainforest. Of the 27-kilometre road, only 1 1/4 kilometres runs through prime rainforest. None of the unique scientific areas is within 10 kilometres of that road. The road was put through an area that is naturally a high stress area because it faces the eastern seaboard and it is totally at the mercy of cyclonic winds and all the rest of it. So it is a high stress area. Once one passes those 1 1/4 kilometres, one starts to see eucalyptus trees and then on to hardwood ridges and what was once open grassland. In total, 75,050 hectares of rainforest is included in the Daintree National Park and the Cape Tribulation National Park. Thus, 75,050 hectares is in national parks that cannot be logged. The total area is 190,000 hectares and of that 750 hectares is available for logging. There is only one small operator. I think his total take is about 3,120 cubic metres a year and he has not achieved that result.

The history in Queensland of looking after rainforests is a tremendous one. The trouble is that that is not being recognised because we get the ridiculous statements from the lunatic fringe such as: `There will be nothing left in one year or two years'. We have to take a positive look at our conservation methods. We do need timber. Everybody accepts that we need timber in many ways, shapes and forms. We are a net importer of timber to the value of about $700m a year, in an economy which has a massive current account deficit.

Our foresters, particularly those in Tasmania and Queensland, on which States the debate has centred today, are good foresters. At the same time as they are selectively logging, they are maintaining the areas for future generations. Senator Sanders has not yet ever told us where we are likely to get our timber from in the future, except from massive imports. We have a natural resource which, because of the expertise of our foresters, is being selectively logged and thus preserved for future generations. So we have a very good record. This is important. As I have said, whether we like it or not, we have an effect on our environment. It is a question of how we regulate that effect, how we maintain those resources for future generations. As I said when I put down that definition, I do not disagree with it. It states that at the same time as maintaining our resources for the future we can selectively use them so that we make the best use of those resources now and ensure that they are preserved for future generations.

Both the Tasmanian and Queensland governments have a tremendous record in husbanding and farming those resources so that we can use them and at the same time preserve them and also lock away the areas that are unique and of scientific value. As I have said, 750,000 hectares in Queensland will not be logged. Twenty-six per cent of the land mass in Tasmania will not be logged. Such is the responsible attitude taken by those two governments, at the same time as providing a much needed resource for this country, a much needed industry for Tasmania, much needed jobs in Tasmania and much needed timber for present and future generations.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although I was elected on the single issue of nuclear disarmament and some senatorial colleagues may be surprised to hear me speaking in this debate, I want to point out the close link between nuclear disarmament and the protection of our fragile environment. I cannot let go unchallenged Senator Collard's remarks that the Queensland and Tasmanian governments are carefully managing their environments. The record in both of those States is abysmal.

SPEECH.PARA: As well as making sure that there is a future for our children, their children and so on by ensuring that we do not self-destruct by using nuclear weapons, we need to guard our natural heritage for the benefit, in terms of livelihood and enjoyment, of coming generations. Trees have long been recognised for their positive attributes in providing fresh air by the process of photosynthesis and by providing food and shelter for the world's people. In addition, we must acknowledge that trees are a joy to behold. We should not be so short-sighted as to consider short term gains as more important than the protection of our forests which are such a valuable, limited and fast diminishing resource.

The Federal Government has already lost the support of the youth of Australia because of its lack of resolve on nuclear issues. On environmental issues the Government still has a chance to appeal to young people. But, if it sells out on woodchipping and the Daintree, there will be little hope of recovering youth support. I wish to quote the opening sentence in the foreword of a booklet `Environment, Conservation and Heritage' released by the Hon. Barry Cohen last week. In it the Minister states:

Since it came to office in 1983 the Government's strong commitment to the protection and conservation of the nation's natural and cultural heritage has been reflected in many important initiatives, most notably preventing construction of the Gordon-below-Franklin dam in South-West Tasmania.

Indeed, that was a very welcome initiative. What a great tragedy it would be if, having saved the Franklin, the Federal Government did not carry out its obligations to help preserve this unique wilderness area that mainland woodchipping companies are wanting to destroy.

There are four major wilderness areas in question. They represent only 10 per cent of the available timber resource. Surely the companies should be content with having the other 90 per cent. The southern forests in South West Tasmania represent Australia's largest forested wilderness. Their loss would be a disaster comparable to the flooding of Lake Pedder. The Western Tiers, the Lemon-Thyme and the forests of the Douglas and Apsley rivers are all unique areas that must be protected.

The decision on Tasmanian woodchipping will have repercussions in New South Wales, Victoria and Western Australia. It is unacceptable that this part of our precious environment, our forests, which we have a duty to caretake for future generations, should be reduced to woodchips for sale overseas. In regard to the other forest area that is threatened by careless development, I urge the Government to ensure the protection of the Daintree by recommending its listing as part of the world heritage area. The same insanity that is threatening this planet with nuclear destruction is threatening our unique environment. I hope that the Government is sincere in its claims that it intends to protect these areas. The people of Australia want more than words; they want action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to have the opportunity to speak on behalf of the Government in this debate this afternoon because I feel that I am probably uniquely qualified to discuss the issues that have been raised. As a fourth generation Tasmanian I have some understanding of some of the concerns that were raised earlier, and I can certainly appreciate those concerns. However, I cannot accept a number of misrepresentations that have been made in the Senate this afternoon. I think that the Government's record speaks for itself and it is quite clear that the urgency motion, as has been detailed for us by Senator Sanders, has not even been addressed by any of the speakers. It is quite clear that in regard to the urgency motion today we are supposed to be debating the Government's apparent betrayal of trust in failing to protect world heritage forests. That is what we are supposed to be debating.
—Do they mention what Minister Kerin is doing?
—The honourable senator seems to have a very close knowledge of what Minister Kerin, Minister Cohen and, indeed, what the Federal Cabinet are about to discuss on 16 December.
—They released the statement.

—Never mind, Senator. I suggest he should be patient and await the outcome. The Government's record is abundantly clear and indicates that there has been no betrayal of anyone by the Hawke Labor Government. In regard to rainforests, the report entitled `Objectives, achievements and priorities in Environment, Conservation and Heritage' states that the Federal Government has:

SPEECH.PARA: Offered the Queensland Government a package of proposals for the protection of the rainforests of the wet tropics of north-east Queensland which include the rainforests in the Daintree and Downey Creek areas.
Co-operated with the New South Wales Government in nominating areas of New South Wales rainforests for World Heritage Listing.

Convened in 1984 a conference in Cairns involving representatives of Commonwealth, State and Territory governments, conservation groups, unions and the timber industry to discuss the development of a national policy on rainforest conservation.

Established a Working Group, comprising a broad spectrum of rainforest interests, including government, industry, conservation and union representatives, to advise the Government on the development of a Commonwealth Rainforest Conservation Policy. The report by the Working Group to the Minister for Arts, Heritage and Environment has been made available for public comment.

I ask you, Mr Acting Deputy President: Does that really sound like a betrayal? That sounds like action. Of course, the Australian Democrats do not like the fact that the Hawke Labor Government has taken very significant steps. They do not like the fact that we are acting. They would rather put forward this very misleading urgency motion this afternoon. Let us look at this betrayal that they are so concerned about. I would like to read briefly from a Press release of 15 March 1985 which shows how much betrayal is going on between the Hawke Labor Government and the Gray Government:

The following statement was issued after the first meeting of the Ministerial Council on the Management of the World Heritage area in Hobart yesterday. The meeting was chaired by the Premier of Tasmania, the Hon. Robin Gray.

In introductory comments opening the meeting both the Premier and Mr Cohen indicated a mutual wish by their governments to work together to develop one of the best national parks in the world and to maximise benefits that would be derived for Tasmania.

Mr Gray said that the Council reached agreement on a range of matters which formalised the consultative and management structures that would operate in the administration and development of the World Heritage Area.

It seems that the Democrats, in particular Senator Sanders, are not very happy when governments try to co-operate. They would rather that we had on-going confrontation. Frankly, I can sympathise with Senator Sanders because I appreciate that his view is very different from Premier Gray's view, just as I have moments of absolute frustration in trying to deal with the Queensland Government. Nevertheless, the Federal Government has a responsibility to try to negotiate. Negotiation is the option that Minister Cohen has adopted. Lo and behold, it seems that his option is successful. In regard to the extent to which this betrayal is going on in Queensland, I refer to a headline. Certainly, I almost fainted when I saw the headline, but it seems that Minister Cohen has been able to get the Premier of Queensland to negotiate. The headline of an article which appeared on 2 November 1985 reads: `Sir Joh willing to negotiate on forests plan'. Let us be positive for a change. Let us look at whether it is possible on occasions to negotiate and get some sort of co-operation with the Gray Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government. The article reads:
The Queensland government was willing to negotiate on a $200m federal plan to save Australia's rainforests, the Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, said yesterday.
The plan, prepared for the Federal Environment Minister, Mr Cohen, by the Rainforest Working Party, involves acquiring forests to ensure their preservation.
Most of Australia's rainforest is in northern Queensland.
Sir Joh said he spoke with Mr Cohen in Cairns on Tuesday and asked for the proposal to be put formally in writing.
Mr Cohen is still to take the plan to Federal Cabinet for approval.
Sir Joh said he had made it clear that he would not be a party to joint Commonwealth/State ownership of the acquired forests.
This would be a serious erosion of State rights.
There we find the Queensland Premier resorting to his usual tactics. But I ask Senator Sanders: Where is this betrayal of trust?

TALK.START.PARA: —Right here in this document entitled `Rainforest Conservation in Australia' which has been tabled in this Parliament. You have betrayed this trust.

—I cannot see how Minister Cohen has betrayed anybody in regard to rainforests. Let us turn to what has actually been said in this place this afternoon. We had a dissertation on the Tasmanian woodchip industry by Senator Sanders. I must admit that I have some agreement with some of the concerns that he raised. However, I place on the record very clearly some misrepresentations that he made in regard to the Hawke Government. He presented his urgency motion so hurriedly that he presented it to the wrong person and we nearly did not have this debate this afternoon. But he was obviously in such a hurry that he did not quite get the wording right. It is quite clear that the forests in the existing World Heritage area in Tasmania are not under threat. That is the whole point of this debate this afternoon. The Tasmanian world heritage area consists entirely of three national parks gazetted under Tasmanian legislation. There is no intention on the part of the State or the Commonwealth governments to log them. If there were an intention on the part of Robin Gray, the Federal Government states categorically that it would not allow logging in world heritage areas of Tasmania.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us turn to the area to which Senator Sanders was referring. He was referring to areas other than existing world heritage areas. Certainly, in regard to western Tasmanian National Estate forests outside the world heritage area, the Federal Government is seeking to ensure that National Estate values, including wilderness, are not downgraded. Cabinet will make a decision on how to do this on 16 December. We have heard this alarmist nonsense from Senator Sanders long before the decision has been made. Senator Sanders obviously believes that he is privy to the thoughts of Minister Kerin, the thoughts of Minister Cohen and the thoughts of the entire Cabinet. The decision has not yet been made. The Federal Government has indicated that it would prefer to proceed through consultation and discussion. That is the preference of the Hawke Labor Government. It has built its reputation on consultation and consensus. It has had to deal with some very intransigent State governments. The Tasmanian Government is one and the Queensland Government is another. Nevertheless, the Hawke Government is a particularly patient government and keeps trying to negotiate and consult and get those governments to see reason. The Minister has advised quite clearly that we will proceed through consultation and discussion with the Tasmanian Government. Several meetings at an official level already have been held. Mr Kerin has met with Premier Gray. Furthermore, he has stated that where forestry options conflict with National Estate values forestry operations will not proceed. That was reported in the Hobart Mercury. I am not in a position to read the Mercury these days, but I presume that Senator Sanders would be able to find that statement by Minister Kerin if he bothered to search it out.

Let me now turn my attention to rainforests in north Queensland. I take exception to Senator Collard's statement about the lunatic fringe of the conservation movement. The conservation movement in this country is a very responsible group which does not contain lunatics, either on the fringe or anywhere else. It is important that that be stated quite clearly. We should respect the conservation movement. We should be acknowledging the very fine work it does. Its members should not be dismissed, because they have a point of view different from that of Senator Collard, as lunatics. That is certainly a description I could apply to a number of members of the Queensland Government, but on this occasion I would be far too polite to do so.

In regard to the Daintree issue, I have been well placed to follow the confrontation. Of course the Queensland Government has been intransigent. Of course the Daintree road should never have been built. I worked very hard, along with a number of other Government members, to try to stop that road being built. But it was a State prerogative. Minister Cohen offered funding for an alternative route but the Queensland Government was not interested in protecting and preserving that unique area. It was more concerned about confronting the Federal Government. Therefore, it refused all reasonable overtures from the Hawke Government. It was more interested in confrontation.

To give credit where credit is due-it hurts me somewhat to have to accept that the Queensland Premier is at last talking a little sense-if the Queensland Premier is prepared to negotiate on Minister Cohen's excellent rainforest management plan and if it is true, as Senator Collard indicated to us, that the Queensland Government is anxious to protect its last remaining rainforest area, the responsibility goes back to the State Government to nominate those areas for World Heritage listing. The Queensland Premier has moved several steps forward. He wants to co-operate with Canberra. We should all be celebrating. If he is genuinely prepared to co-operate with Canberra, he should make that official by nominating the north Queensland rainforest area for inclusion on the World Heritage List. That would be a nice seasonal gesture. It would show that the Hawke Labor Government and the Bjelke-Petersen Government on occasions can agree. I move:
That the question be now put.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I seek the leave of the Senate to make a statement to try to correct some of the highly inaccurate and misleading views that have been deceiving a great majority of people as a result of Senator Sanders's statements.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! There can be no debate. The question must be put.

INTERJECT.PARA: That the motion (Senator Sanders's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Mason Sen C.V.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, I seek leave to make a personal explanation because I claim to have been misrepresented by an article in the Sydney Daily Mirror of last Friday.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer to an article headlined `Lunch-Tax Rebels Put Bite On Chipp' on page 3 of the Sydney Daily Mirror. I might say that that is a typical Sydney afternoon headline. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: Two rebel Australian Democrats are set to renege on party leader Don Chipp over his controversial lunch-tax deal with Treasurer Paul Keating.
The mutineers, angry because the package has done nothing to halt the entertainment tax . . . threaten to vote against it.
That party is hopeful of winning over one of the dissidents.
But defiant New South Wales member Colin Mason is thought certain to cross the floor of the Senate to vote with the Opposition against the so-called nasty elements of the legislation.

I do not normally like to indicate in advance how I will vote on legislation, but this article is so blatantly wrong and so completely opposite to the views that I have put consistently at all meetings and to the media that it positively staggers me. I will be voting with the Government for this legislation, and I have always made that view clear.

Two points arise which I would like to make as a result of this article. I think they are of concern to honourable senators. The first point is that the authors of the article made no contact whatsoever with me or with my office before this story was written. The second point is that on Sunday--

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Senator Mason is talking about something that is on the Notice Paper. Why the heck should he be allowed to stand up and say what he will do? We do not know what the Democrats will do. One can never tell.
—Order! Senator Mason has been given leave to make a personal explanation. The discussion of the behaviour of others is not relevant to the personal explanation.

—I am obliged to my friend and colleague Senator Townley for his very sage intervention. The second point I would like to make is serious, and it is something that the Senate ought to consider. A reporter from the Mirror rang me on Sunday night at my home and canvassed this story with me. At that time I had not seen Friday's Mirror. The reporter said: `This rumour is around'. I said that it was absolutely untrue. I set out the situation and explained my reasons. Since that time, no statement has appeared in the Mirror. I talked to the editor of the Mirror today and, as far as I can gather, something will appear in that newspaper tomorrow.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Opposition parties welcome the statement that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made last week in the House of Representatives. It is a pity that we each have only five minutes to speak to it now. There is no doubt that the history of women in Australia has been one of repressed economic, social and political status. The agenda which the Prime Minister has put down is an attempt to overcome some of the disadvantages faced by women. For the last decade the governments of the world have joined together to acknowledge and to alleviate this problem. The Prime Minister's statement comes soon after the official ending of the United Nations Decade for Women. For much of that decade the Liberal and National parties were in government in this country. Our record is one of contribution towards overcoming some of the problems and the achievement of some of the goals which many women have sought.

In our society, women have traditionally taken on the responsibility for the young and for the family-the role of carer and of nurturer. Our parties maintain that a recognition of the maternal and child caring and rearing role which women have undertaken is very important not only to society but also because it has a very important cultural, economic and social significance of its own. We recognise those facts, but there is no doubt that women have found it more difficult to achieve equal opportunity because of the role which they have taken on. I refer to the double role which many women are forced to undertake if they wish to discharge their duties and to participate fully in other avenues which society can offer.

The maternal and caring role has led to special social and financial burdens for women. The Opposition understands this and wishes to be part of any reasonable steps which can overcome those problems. These burdens have not always been adequately shared by men. For example, the role of home maker, the nurturing role and the caring role are often left to women, and those roles are not seen as something in which many men need to be or should be involved.

I am proud to belong to a party which has had so much involvement over the last decade in the advancement of women's opportunities. It was the Liberal Party which in 1976 which established the Office of Child Care, introduced the family allowance scheme which moved money from the wallet to the purse for the first time, set up special women's units in a number of government departments, altered the Superannuation Acts to make new arrangements for equal provisions for women public servants and established the women's film fund. In 1977 it was the Liberal Government which established the National Women's Advisory Council, and in 1978 it established the home rehabilitation services section in the Office of Women's Affairs. We established shop-front information offices between 1979 and 1983 and we increased and improved the benefit for supporting parents, most of whom are women who have become supporting parents as a result of family breakdown.

The Party to which I belong at the moment happens to have women presidents in its two largest divisions. I refer also to Jenny Adamson in South Australia. She has been a Cabinet Minister and is one of the prominent members of the South Australian Parliament. Many women have been active politically in our Party.

The only thing I want to say in the few seconds remaining is that we are aware of the strains of the double role which many women bear. We are aware of the importance of providing adequate child care. We are aware of the issue of equal employment opportunity. All of these issues need to be addressed if some of the goals laid down by the Prime Minister are to be achieved. As Mr Howard said, and as I want to say now, the Opposition wishes to participate as far as it is able in the achievement of those goals. There will be disagreements on detail, but to the extent that we can establish a bipartisan approach on some of the goals of equal opportunity for women, the Opposition wishes to be part of that effort.

TALK.START.PARA: —I call Senator Crowley.
—Show him that you can be magnanimous.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The advice flowing is to be remarked. I take note of Senator Peter Baume's comments, which are a matter of record. We would be clear, though, that this Government would take issue with what he regards as small points of detail on some of the issues. One has only to recall the Opposition's difficulties in the sex discrimination legislation to appreciate that matters of difficulty can become major obstacles when it comes to debating and passing legislation.
—How did we vote? Look at the voting divisions.

—It is a matter of note that, as Senator Baume says, during the time in which there was a Liberal government in the past decade some achievements were made for women, but it is a matter of considerable pride and satisfaction to be part of a government that has achieved so much in the past three years, on top of what Senator Baume claims to have been some of the gains and achievements for women before that. It is clear also as a matter of political record that there is considerable dissension in the Opposition ranks about how far and in what detail support for women's movements and women's requirements should go. Whilst Senator Baume has mentioned some women in South Australia, particularly Jenny Adamson, I am reminded also of another significant South Australian woman, Judith Roberts, one time member of the National Women's Advisory Council, who resigned from the Liberal Party of Australia because of its failure to act in support of achievements and legislation for women.

SPEECH.PARA: The National Agenda for Women is a record of the considerable achievements of the Government. More importantly, it points to what the Government has set out as the headlines of the agenda for its proposals up to the year 2000. As the document points out, it follows on from the conference in Nairobi to mark the end of the Decade for Women. A couple of points need to be made about that conference. In particular I remark, as I have on a few previous occasions in this chamber, on the interesting and very remarkable response to the Australian Government's presentation of its report on the achievements for women in this country over the past 10 years. That presentation was given by Senator Patricia Giles, the leader of our delegation. Many people were particularly interested to take up some of the comments raised in that report. In particular people were interested in the governmental machinery in Australia to provide, at the Federal level anyhow, the overview from the Office of the Status of Women for keeping an eye on all of the portfolio areas with regard to achievements and needs of women. Australia does not have, as other countries do, a department of women's affairs. It has been seen as very important not to allow the hiving off of women from the mainstream considerations and deliberations of government. Many other governments were interested to discuss that with our delegation.

Another very significant point was our reporting that there had been last year, and was to be this year, a fuller women's Budget program. The comprehensive document released at the time of the Budget addressed every portfolio area of the Budget with regard to its effects, directly and indirectly, on women. South Australia this year has produced a women's Budget document with its Budget Papers and one other State-I think Victoria-has produced a women's Budget paper. Again, that document was regarded with considerable interest. I understand that no other country in the world has taken that step on behalf of women and on behalf of helping everybody in the community to focus on the importance and needs of women.

It is a matter of considerable satisfaction and significance that that document has been produced. It goes very much to the core of reminding us not only of the things Senator Peter Baume listed that had been achieved in times past but also of the things achieved during the life of this Labor Government. The significant steps that need noting, despite Senator Walters's claims to the contrary, are the importance of the passage of the Sex Discrimination Act in 1984 and the ratification of the United Nations Convention on the Elimination of All Forms of Discrimination against Women. Those are things that go to changing attitudes as well as behaviour. We cannot move too slowly or far enough in moving to change attitudes about women, women's achievements, and their rights in this community. I am sure that more will be said on the National Agenda for Women up to the year 2000. The document essentially works for women to have a choice, to have a say, to have a fair go. Under all those headings the document spells out the proposals this Government will set in place so that all those areas will be covered and achieved for women.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is with pleasure that I speak on this National Agenda For Women. I am very disappointed that I have been unable to find in the statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) any words in support of women who choose to stay at home.
—Mr Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I have to refer to that comment by Senator Walters. It is a blatant untruth; it is in the document.
—Order! That is not a point of order.

—There is no mention of that section of women who choose to stay at home during their children's formative years and to act as a stabilising influence for their families. There are 10 points outlining what the Government has done, but not one of those 10 points that have been put forward has supported women at home. The Government padded out the points and talked about all sorts of things, such as the Sex Discrimination Act, to which Senator Crowley referred, but it did not mention that the whole of the Sex Discrimination Bill had to be rewritten at the instigation of the Opposition. Indeed, the Government still has not got it right because the Sex Discrimination Commissioner has been forced to discard certain sections of that piece of legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government then referred to affirmative action, but it did not mention that the unions have not yet fallen into line and that there are still some sections where sons of union members are the first put on. I will not go through all of this because I do not have time, but there is no reference in that 10-point plan to women who stay at home and bring up their children during their formative years. On page 3 of the National Agenda for Women the Government talks in a derogatory way about women who stay at home. The wording states that we must be free to achieve economic independence through employment to escape from poverty and dependence. I do not believe that this is the way that women generally see their role in our community. I believe that we do not see ourselves as victims of a male-dominated society. I believe that we see ourselves as partners in a family team and in a work force team. Our status is gained, just as the status of men is gained, via our contribution to that team. Our status derives from the quality of our work, the quality of our family, and the quality of our social life.

I believe that most women see their children as a parental responsibility, not as the Government's responsibility or an employer's responsibility. We do not accept that a woman's status is diminished or her contribution to society lessened by making a choice to join the part time work force or by making a choice not to enter the paid work force. I believe that the current feminist ideology makes it look as though women are in some way inferior if they work fewer hours for less money than men. That is a veiw which assumes, or pretends, that women in the part time work force, no work force or a lower paid work force are being discriminated against. The view held by women is that they are making their choices and they are balancing their degree of responsibility in the paid and unpaid work force with responsibility to their families. The view of the feminists denies the concept of choice and freedom of choice.

It has always been Liberal Party philosophy to support equal opportunity, along with two other basic tenets-freedom of choice and the value of individual choice. The Government does not understand the concept of real choice. If the Government did understand the need for women to have a real choice it would introduce income splitting and allow women to have a real opportunity to make a choice as to whether to stay home and bring up their families or to enter the paid work force. For the Prime Minister to say, in a derogatory fashion, that economic independence is the most important thing for women to enable them to escape from poverty and dependence, I believe, is a disgrace.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —One of the difficulties with addressing papers in this manner is that the period of five minutes is not long enough to enable honourable senators to deal with all of the questions with which they desire to deal. I am sure the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) would be the first to acknowledge that the trade union movement has been responsible for a substantial lift in the status of women in Australia. I recall very well taking one of the first equal pay test cases in this country. It was very hard fought. I also recall putting the argument that it was much more difficult for a woman to sell a pair of shoes to another woman than it was for a man to sell a pair of shoes to another man, yet at that time men were getting paid almost 40 per cent more than women.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn to the report. I am concerned about the fact that, although the report deals with some non-economic matters, it does not deal with a matter which is of concern to a large number of women, if my correspondence is any barometer of that. That is the problem that women see for themselves and for their status with the commercialisation of pornography, as was allowed by this Government from 1 February last year. I am concerned that the report of the Senate Select Committee on Video Material has virtually been ignored by the Government. Many, if not all, of the women who have written to me have expressed concern that they are being treated simply as objects and that the nature of this pornography is a violation of the honour that is due to them.

Let me deal with the subject that Senator Walters raised, which is of great concern to me and must surely be of great concern to the Senate and the people of Australia. Those women who do arguably the most important job in society-the raising and nurturing of the future generation-have been virtually ignored.

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense.

—Let us look at the facts. As of now a mother with four children is $55.35 a month worse off than she was in 1976. Family allowances have lost their value by 50 per cent. In fact, a one-income family on average weekly earnings now pays $785 a year more in tax than a two-income family on an equivalent income. After the much heralded tax package that one-income family will be paying $809 a year more than a two-income family on an equivalent income. If that is giving due recognition to the mother at home, I do not know what the language is all about. I am happy to see that the Prime Minister at least acknowledges the problem on page 7 of his printed statement, when he says:

SPEECH.PARA: It will never with any truth or justice be said of the Labor Government that we are unaware of the tremendous contribution to our national well-being made by women in the home. Without the work they perform the economy would not function as smoothly. At present women's unpaid work in the home and in voluntary activities for the community is not measured and thus tends to be undervalued. In 1988 the Australian Bureau of Statistics will carry out a major time use survey which will provide sound statistical data on women's multiple responsibilities.

I acknowledge that the Prime Minister has finally woken up to the fact that there is a real problem, but something besides this survey needs to be done. Let fairness reign and let the Senate acknowledge that the Prime Minister has indicated that, and we look forward to that result.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise for only two minutes in order to refute the quite blatant misrepresentation by Senator Walters of this very important statement by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) setting the National Agenda for women. I would have to say that Senator Walters's misrepresentation was not only blatant but also deliberate in that there were quotations--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I imagine it is quite in order for the honourable senator, if he thinks there has been an error of fact, so to determine it, but he has imputed a motive to Senator Walters and that is clearly contrary to standing order 418. He said that it was a deliberate misrepresentation.
—I withdraw. Rather than make the imputation myself, I leave it to others to judge. What Senator Walters refused to do was to acknowledge the fact that the Prime Minister said:

SPEECH.PARA: We want to give women the opportunity to contribute to the full to the future development of our nation, whether in a domestic setting, in the workforce, or in any other aspect of life.
After speaking about the opportunities for women in employment he went on to say:
Women must also feel free to choose to be full-time mothers without the fear that their contribution to family life is somehow of a lesser status than work outside the home.
He went on to make other points, stating:

Increasingly Australian women choose different roles at different stages of their lives. Many women want to leave the workforce to nurture their young children and then be able to return to employment without having to start at the bottom again.
In the past, economic factors and social prejudices have constrained women's choices and women have often been seen only in their familial roles as wives or mothers. Nevertheless-
I quote this for Senator Walters's special benefit-

family life is the central focus for very many Australian women and the Labor Government is committed to giving support to families, and recognises the wide variety of family structures now chosen by Australians.

Finally, just to reinforce the point made by Senator Harradine, it is one thing to express those sentiments, and they have to be acknowledged as having been expressed, and it is another to have the statistical base to form government policies to implement the consequences of that acknowledgment. Here the Labor Government has said:
At present women's unpaid work in the home and in voluntary activities for the community is not measured and thus tends to be undervalued.
He points out:
In 1988 the Australian Bureau of Statistics will carry out a major time use survey which will provide sound statistical data on women's multiple responsibilities.

I put those facts on the record as a complete refutation of Senator Walters's partial quoting and blatant misrepresentation. I leave it, as I say, to others to judge as to the accuracy of her contribution.
Debate (on motion by Senator Ryan) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

My criticism of the statement by the Foreign Minister (Mr Hayden) on the Australian overseas aid program is not about what is in the statement but what is not in the statement. The response by the Minister deals more with the general approach and philosophy of aid rather than with the specific recommendations contained in both the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program and the findings of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the Jackson report. Positive matters in the report include the acceptance by the Government of a `commitment to work towards achieving the equivalent of 0.7 per cent of gross national product on overseas aid', and the decision `that the Government has decided that the real level of official development aid will increase yearly in the future'. The Government has accepted the basic assessment that aid is given primarily for humanitarian reasons to promote development, but it also complements our strategic, economic and foreign policy interests.

In regard to Papua New Guinea-our largest aid recipient-the Government will provide continuing high levels of aid but with a 3 per cent real annual rate of decline. The Joint Committee, while supporting the goal of reducing the dependence of Papua New Guinea on Australian aid, referred to the importance of an adequate level of dialogue. This dialogue would maintain the close relationship which currently exists between our two countries.

Other initiatives which I welcome are the upgrading of the Australian Development Assistance Bureau to make it more professional, which will mean that administrative costs will rise from 1.54 per cent to 1.7 per cent. That upgrading is overdue, especially if it leads to increased efficiency. Another initiative which I welcome is the recognition of non-government organisations, which will receive $18.2m in 1985-86. Activities to assist women will receive $500,000 in 1985-86 and development and initiatives in education and development research will receive $149,000. My major disappointment with the Minister's response is in relation to the African Development Bank. In his statement, the Minister announced.
We have taken steps to look into the possibility of membership of the African Development Bank.
However, let me quote from the report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on the issue of the African Development Bank:

5.54 A strong case has been put forward for joining the AfDB on procurement grounds alone. Australian companies cannot compete for contracts awarded by the AfDB until we become a member. It has been put to this Committee that a number of Australian companies `have had first hand experience of lost business in consulting and supplier opportunities because of Australia's non-membership'. The Department of Trade although not expressing any opinion on the merits or otherwise of joining, informed the Committee that:

[the consultants industry, in particular, see membership] as being another opportunity for them. They argue that if we did join they would be able to do better than our contribution in terms of the contracts won, because of the nature of the contracts being let by the AfDB.

The Department of Housing and Construction also endorsed the Jackson recommendation noting that Australian industry has the talents and expertise that could be used in African development given an appropriate entree.

5.55 The Treasury drew attention to a United States Treasury report which, in 1982, inferred that the AfDB, although ranking high on humanitarian grounds, was not as efficient as the other regional development banks. This Committee is advised that the AfDB did face considerable problems in the early stages of its operations and, by comparison with what are regarded as three of the most efficient development institutions in the world (the International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (IBRD), AsDB and IDB), it was not regarded as having the same level of performance. However, since that report was issued, a new management structure has been established with the accession to full Bank membership of 21 non-regional members. Non-regional membership includes all of the western donors with the exception of Australia and New Zealand.

5.56 The AFDB is increasingly recognised as a soundly functioning institution. A recent study by Kidder, Peabody and Co. (a major USA firm of Corporate Financial Analysts who have prepared a series of studies on the international financial institutions for submission to the United States Congress) concluded that `from our analysis of the Bank's capital structure, financial condition, operating history and member country support together with its conservative loan operating and liquidity policies, it is our opinion that the AfDB is among the premier financial credits in the international capital markets. Moreover, we are confident that the African Development Bank will continue to strengthen its fine operating performance in the future and continue to fully merit the premium credit ratings assigned to its securities'. This conclusion is reflected in its current credit ratings which are now directly comparable with those of the Asian, Inter-American and World Banks.

As a result, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence recommended that positive consideration should be given to seeking early membership of the African Development Bank. If Australia was to request membership immediately, we could not join before 1987 because there is a waiting list. I am afraid that the Treasury view will win out despite the fact that it gave misleading or at least out of date evidence to the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. Therefore, I believe that the Government should join the African Development Bank as soon as possible.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Georges Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a statement on behalf of the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts concerning its inquiry into computer acquisition.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament is aware that the Joint Parliamentary Committee of Public Accounts has been given a standing reference to examine and report on major automatic data processing acquisition proposals which exceed $5m before they proceed to Cabinet for funding approval. When examining these proposals the Committee seeks to ensure that they are properly planned and justified. However, it also recognises that if the Commonwealth is to get value for money from these proposals, subsequent purchasing action must also proceed in line with approved procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee has been conducting an inquiry into the job seeker computer acquisition and related aspects of the ADP operations of the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations. The job seeker project is intended to provide storage and update facilities for job seeker registration records through a network of computers located in Commonwealth Employment Service offices throughout Australia. This inquiry resulted from advice to the Committee of an unusual level of disquiet in the computer vendor industry about the conduct of this tender and from serious criticisms made by the Auditor-General in his September 1985 report about the adequacy of planning, cost-benefit justification and financial management supporting a previous ADP project in the Department, job bank.

The Commonwealth's purchasing procedures are there to ensure, among other things, that public tendering is conducted in a thorough and impartial fashion. If these procedures and their purpose are not respected, the reputation of the Commonwealth in the market-place for fair and responsible purchasing practices will be at risk. Responsibility for the proper observance of these procedures rests primarily with the purchasing department although the Department of Local Government and Administrative Services, as the Commonwealth's contracting authority, also has a clear responsibility for ensuring that government purchasing procedures are followed. The Committee has been concerned to avoid unnecessary delay in its examination of the job seeker acquisition. It has therefore expedited its inquiries and is now in a position to provide a statement to the Parliament about its conclusions.
The Committee's concerns about the job seeker computer acquisition are twofold.

Firstly, the Committee has serious concerns about several documented instances during the evaluation of tenders, where proper procedures were not followed. The Committee has also noted some unusual and, in its view, unacceptable features of the recommended tender and proposed contractual arrangements with the recommended tenderer. Secondly, the Committee is not satisfied that adequate planning and evaluation was undertaken to support the particular implementation strategy chosen for the job seeker project. It has also noted the serious criticisms made by the Auditor-General of the Department's past performance in the conduct of proper planning and evaluation for the job bank project. The Committee will be providing a full report to Parliament on these matters in due course.

The Committee has concluded that the tendering procedures may have compromised the impartiality of the tender recommendation, but it has also given careful consideration to the considerable costs resulting from tender cancellation and the consequent delay in the implementation of the job seeker project. Reluctantly, it has concluded that these costs would outweigh the benefits resulting from the conduct of a new tender. The Committee is, therefore, recommending that the job seeker purchase proceed, subject to certain amendments being made to the proposed contract with the recommended supplier. The Committee is also recommending that before any further ADP procurement action is taken by the Department, it undertake a comprehensive re-evaluation of its future ADP needs and represent the outcome in a revised ADP strategic plan. This should be supported by full documentation of the planning and justification for all proposed ADP acquisitions over the next three years. Of course, the Committee would expect that any ADP acquisition proposal costing more than $5m would be referred to the Committee for examination and report under its standing reference. The Committee will be communicating its recommendations on these matters in greater detail to the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations and the Minister for Local Government and Administrative Services.
