DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1985COMMONWEALTH EDUCATION INSTITUTIONS (OVERSEAS STUDENTS) AMENDMENT BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1985

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Prior to the suspension of the sitting for lunch we were discussing the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985 and the Bills which we are debating cognately. I was concentrating my remarks on the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 3). I mentioned the restrictions placed on tertiary institutions by the Minister's guidelines which ignore the reality that there is already a great concentration of overseas students at a few institutions in Australia. This may occur for good academic reasons and need not be discouraged.

SPEECH.PARA: One contentious issue relating to the entry of overseas students into Australian tertiary institutions is the extent to which such students keep Australian students out. This is the cause of bitterness and misunderstanding. It conceals the real reason why some Australians who otherwise qualify for tertiary places are denied entry. The reason is that funding restrictions by the Government and increased demand force universities and colleges to impose more and more rigid quotas for entry. They, like hospitals under Medicare, are forced to ration places in a free system. As a result, many potential students miss out. Estimates vary but the number may well be as high as 30,000 for Australia in a year. There are certainly many thousands in my State of Queensland. The figures vary between 8,000 and 20,000 students who will miss out. These are deserving students. In such circumstances it is most unfortunate, but understandable, that those who miss out are upset when they see many overseas students coming in. Their reactions will only be reinforced when they observe that from now on overseas students will have two chances of gaining access to our tertiary institutions. They will qualify either as subsidised students who pay the overseas students charge or as full fee paying students.

Our own students are to be denied the latter opportunity for reasons that are not apparent. It is odd under the circumstances that the Minister claims, as she did in her March statement, that the new program will safeguard the rights of Australian students. I doubt whether those students or their parents will believe her. Perhaps the only way that some Australian students will be able to study the course of their choice will be to emigrate and then apply for entry as fee paying students. It is strange that at the same time as some Australian students are missing out others are continuing to be subsidised to drop out half way through their courses, without any financial obligation, while others are allowed to take many more years than necessary to complete their courses. However, as the Minister says: `Don't let anyone tell you that our education system is inequitable or inefficient'.

The problem is not that overseas students are allowed to pay full fees; the problem is that Australian students are not. Yet in a remarkable Press release on 17 October last entitled `Shack misses the point-again' the Minister claimed:
He is asking for the impossible. Our higher education system is merit based. He is calling for a policy that would replace merit by ability to pay.

This ignores the fact that under such an arrangement students would still be required to fulfil academic entry requirements. The Minister does not seem to realise that those currently missing out are qualified for entry already. The Minister's statement is even more remarkable when it is realised that many overseas students coming in at present are not selected solely on merit. As the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Overseas Aid Program stated:

Students from developing countries applying for Australian Government scholarships must satisfy a multitude of requirements in their own countries and in Australia. They must be approved by their own government and are often selected on grounds other than academic merit. The criteria of the more influential government departments in developing countries tend to prevail. In practice, the process is something of a lottery because students and officials in developing countries are usually poorly informed about the range of courses available.

This makes nonsense of remarks about merit. It also reveals the rigidity of an education system which is monopolised by government and which prevents institutions from seeking their own levels of excellence. It is ironic that many overseas students who choose to come to Australia do so because of the parlous state of education policies in their own countries. In each case presented to me, subsidised students were studying here in Canberra at the Australian National University because of the inability to gain entry to a tertiary institution in their own country. Various reasons-political or whatever-were given for that.

It is all very well to seek education export markets. In fact, I think I indicated earlier in my remarks that that is a very praiseworthy thing to do. Usually however a country exports goods surplus to its own domestic requirements. We have the curious situation of seeking exports when we have an untenable education deficit which is of concern to thousands of young Australians and their parents.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Usually about this time each year we look at the States grants Bills. It is a useful opportunity to review the position of education in Australia and where the education system might be going, particularly from a point of view of funding at the Commonwealth level. Of course, the Commonwealth being a major funder of education either directly or through the States grants is a major determinant of what is likely to happen to education and how it is likely to happen in the ensuing years. To put it into some perspective, in 1976-77 Budget expenditure on education constituted 9.2 per cent of total Budget outlays. In 1982-83 this dropped to 7.9 per cent. In this year's Budget it dropped to 7.1 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Fairly obviously the operation we are seeing in Australia is directed at a decreasing priority for education vis-a-vis other priorities which both this Government and the previous Government have had. From 1974-75 through to 1982-83 the total Commonwealth expenditure on private schools increased by 107 per cent in real terms and expenditure on public schools increased by 18 per cent in real terms. I think those figures, which are contained in the Quality of Education Review Committee report, are interesting. When one looks at the total expenditure one sees the same type of expenditure pattern in both Commonwealth and State education expenditures. Of course, State governments are the major funders of public schools. Thus we see the same relative increase in private school and public school expenditure.

An economist, Ross Williams, has estimated that the private dollar spent on private schooling has fallen. For example, the 1981-82 expenditure level was less than one third of the 1968-69 level. In other words, over the years the amount of money which has been able to be placed in the private school sector by those people attending private schools has dropped. It is Ross Williams's estimate that the rise in the number of people attending private schools can be explained very well by this change in expenditure of the private dollar.

The reason I raise this issue is that it is a component of the major education debate which took place in Australia this year concerning educational standards. A large component of that debate revolved around the differences between private and public schools. In general that debate was not of course of a terribly high calibre. One of the major contributions to that debate was made by Greg Sheridan writing in the Bulletin magazine. Amongst a variety of statements he said:
All around the country teachers are giving our children a diet of intellectual poison.
That debate was fuelled by Professor Chipman when he said:
An Australian Education Council of Education Research survey done a few years ago reported that one sixth of the 14 year olds sampled were unable to read a single sentence.
No doubt he was referring to the 1975 Australian Council for Educational Research survey of numeracy and literacy. If one refers to that survey one finds the statement:

From the evidence available we have estimated the proportion of students in normal schooling at the ten year old and 14 year old levels who were unable to read simple sentences to be 3% and .8% respectively.

Of course there is a considerable difference, as most people would realise, between 0.8 per cent and one sixth-which is of course 16.7 per cent. That type of cavalier attitude to available research, saying whatever one wants to say about schooling, flows very much from the attitudes to schooling within our society. All people in society assume themselves to be experts on schools and how they ought to be run. Unlike most other professional areas, schooling is something most people have had a very heavy dose of; many are intimately involved because their own children are at schools. During their formative years they have imbibed a model of how that professional activity should be run. Hence while people would be loath to go into a long discourse on how dentists should run their practices or how doctors should perform medical operations, they feel happy to divest themselves of opinions as to how teachers should teach. That is probably invigorating within our type of community, but those who comment on education and educational matters should pay some attention to what actually happens in the classroom and to the problems faced in schools in our society in 1985.

Let us examine some of those types of problems. The major difficulty in terms of the standards debate to which I have referred previously is that people seem to believe that, no matter when they did their education, nothing has changed in the general social structure. Every time I have raised this matter in debates, discussions and public arenas I have tried to point to some fairly radical changes that have taken place in Australian society in the last few years. Perhaps I can refer to some hard data. When I grew up, presumably when the majority of senators who are now in the chamber grew up-most of them are looking older than I am but it may be just the effects of the end of the year-there was no television. Let us look at what happens to a child today. Some 98 per cent of Australian homes have television sets. The average student in a school career views 15,000 hours of television while consuming 11,500 hours of education. I repeat that students view 15,000 hours of television while they are getting 11,500 hours of contact in the school. That is totally different from what happened to me and to any honourable senator here, and indeed to most parents in Australia today. Let us take that single item and try to work through the types of ramifications that must have for the classroom environment. Let us have a little understanding of the changes that have taken place and the impact of those changes outside the classroom, outside the school, on what happens in the classroom and what happens to teachers.

While students are viewing those 15,000 hours of television, they are watching 500,000 advertisements. It may be a bit too harsh to say that all those advertisements undermine the logic that schools attempt to teach, but what we do know about them is that many advertisements are pitched at certain types of value structures in our society. That is another constituent part of this whole debate about standards, about dropping values, about the problems when teachers are no longer imposing discipline on pupils-as though discipline were applied by only teachers in our society. The constituent parts of our society, such as the home, church, the school but also the media, surely must bear part of the blame at least for any of those types of changing social values. If parents are content to allow their children to watch 15,000 hours of television, should not the home perhaps accept the effect of some of the changes that might take place as a result of that viewing? Let us have a slightly more sensible debate in 1986 about education and what is going on than simply to say: `It is the schools and the teachers that are responsible for what is happening'. If our society wants an advertising industry and supports such an industry, we have to accept the problems of the advertising industry and what it does to young people. So do our families, the churches and every other organ in our society, and so does the media.

TALK.START.PARA: —No one is denying all this.

—If one reads those advertisements and the types of articles that appear in the media, one would think that the media had absolutely no influence on the type of values in our society. The mass media have reduced every authority that exists outside themselves in terms of what has gone on, yet they wish to criticise every other function in society except themselves. I believe it is about time that we tried to get some balance of those various competing sections of the society that we have and what they do to the general value structures in our society and what those value structures do to the education system. We cannot have a weakening of the family, the churches, or of all other groups within society without there being concomitant results in the classroom. One cannot have exploitation of sex to sell consumer products in this society without there being some type of backlash in the classroom and without pressure in the classroom to try to go into various courses on human relationships. It is all very well then for people to ask, as did Greg Sheridan in the article he wrote in the Bulletin, `What about these mushy courses on human relationships?' without at the same time condemning the exploitation of sex that takes place in the Bulletin. It is that exploitation that leads directly to demands within our society to have those human education courses.

SPEECH.PARA: Schools are responding to the demands placed upon them. Those demands arise out of the changes in our social structures. Let us have a little fairness in these matters, when those types of things are talked about, to try to pinpoint the origin of the types of value structures and changes that take place rather than the simplistic mush that is churned out as though it were some type of education debate. I hope that in 1986 we may see some strengthening of the genuine types of debates. I have already pointed to the exploitation of sex. There are other aspects, such as the programs of daily news and current affairs which are churned out to our young people, which was not the case in earlier days. This gives rise to a whole range of discussions-for example, in regard to acquired immune deficiency syndrome. What is a teacher to do in the classroom when children present controversial problems of this type? Is the teacher to sweep such matters under the carpet? Of course not. Yet when I grew up, matters of that type were outside our understanding. We just did not come across them unless we were avid readers of the newspaper. I grew up in a small country town and I am sure that our newspaper would not have carried such material. What one got was what one heard on the radio, and that was it. That was not so long ago and these changes have taken place since then.

Let us try to understand the changes that have taken place and understand how they have affected our family structure in our society. Let us understand how schools are struggling to cope with those changes. It is the schools that first feel the impact of any changes of that type. Let us not all be hypocrites by saying that we support advertising when we fail to see the types of problems that advertising has created in our community. The facade of value neutrality in the classroom has undoubtedly broken down. It is no longer possible for a teacher to hold to that type of facade; namely, that a teacher has neutral values. What is a teacher to do when confronted with somebody who says: `My father says that black people are inferior'? Is the teacher to say one thing on the one hand and something different on the other? Teachers no longer are in a position to be able to skirt round those real, hard, controversial issues. They feel these issues and feel them more than anyone else. It might be useful in 1986 for society to give more support to teachers in all schools than it has given them in the past.

Through that debate on standards ran a thread which I would like to pick up, that is, the rather odd view of comparing and contrasting private and state schools. I have taught in both types of schools, as has my wife. I have spent a fair amount of my professional life visiting both types of schools and looking at people teach in them. Those people who have had that opportunity can say fairly comfortably that the pedagogy in those schools is remarkably similar. I think that is an acceptable statement; I do not think anybody would contest it. However, the choices that people seem to be making are based on some fallacious arguments which pick up the values of credentials as they float around, and undoubtedly credentials from some of the top private schools are more valuable than those from most of the public schools. The reasons for that have nothing to do with education but a lot to do with our social structure. I do not intend to pursue that, but it seems to me to be very odd that people can then generalise from some private schools to all private schools on the one hand, and from some state schools to all state schools on the other hand. I think it would be better if some more discriminating judgments were made between various schools. We have good and bad private schools; we have good and bad public schools.

In many ways, those schools respond to their environments, they respond to the teachers who are in them; and they respond to the problems of the children and their families. In areas where those problems are overwhelmingly ones of economic deprivation, fairly obviously the problems the teachers face are far more difficult than those faced in our more affluent suburbs. When one is confronted at secondary school level with the problem of teaching people to read and write one knows that such difficulties have been compounded over a number of years, not through any fault of the education system but because of the inability of the education system to meet the ever-increasing demands that are placed upon it. I hope that in the credentialling debate-which I think is the real debate with regard to public and private schools-we can be a little more discerning in making those types of distinctions.

I am worried that many of the items pointed to in the Quality of Education Review Committee's report seem to have been missed in the debate this year. For example, in an interesting reference on page 29 of the report-this is something which most people in the education community have known about for a long time-the Committee points to the fact that it is very difficult to come up with hard evidence from employers about students being inadequately prepared for work. The QERC report says that it is mainly anecdotal evidence. We all have a drawer full of anecdotes but the hard evidence is very difficult to get. In respect of the general debate about declining standards, where do we find the hard evidence? When we look at the articles that have been published in the serious journals which attempts to review all the educational research in this area, we see statements such as this one by Graeme Little in Standards of Education in Australia:
The fact remains that the hard data we have refutes the decline theory . . . This is not to say that we do not know whether there has been a decline. We do know that there has not been a decline.

It does not matter how many times we refer to these studies, this hoary myth seems to hang around. That is a pity because there are many other areas of the education debate that need urgent attention. We can do without the constant reiteration of that type of material.

We have already debated the problem of exiting from our secondary schools. For example, we find that 45 per cent of Australians in the 15 to 19 year-old bracket are engaged in full time post-compulsory education compared with 75 per cent in the equivalent age group in the United States of America. Why should this be the case? Is it that our students are not as academically bright, not as capable of undertaking post-secondary education? Of course it is not. It is a legacy of the attitude the community in general and successive governments have taken to the funding of education in this country. I think that has to be made top priority next year.

Senator Peter Baume in his speech during the second reading debate referred to our odd priorities-looking at racehorses and a number of other matters rather than at the education of our own citizens and their future. Undoubtedly the Government can say that if it leaves the educational structure as it is, if it maintains the funding in roughly the same configuration as it is at the moment, there probably will not be any electoral backlash arising out of this. I hope that we might go beyond that rather thin political debate and point to the fact that the problems we faced in Australia in the last few years have stemmed directly from the neglect of education in the post-war years. Our States having constantly underfunded their schooling systems and the fact that we have constantly underfunded schools in the public sector and, probably more heinously, in the private sector, including our research efforts, have led to the present parlous state of the economy. We know that money invested in education provides the best return on money invested anywhere-and that includes hole in the ground mining, agriculture, and every other possible industry. We know this and we have known it for a long time, yet we constantly neglect it.

The tertiary sector has suffered a series of blows this year. The various top priorities enunciated by the Government are being shunted into the background. A decision was made in May to cut the capital works funding in technical and further education by $12m and a campaign is running at this time which suggests that youth is a top priority. I am not sure how all those things go together. I do not think they do. A rigorous pursuit of the needs in this area is necessary to maintain the level of funding, to increase the level of funding, and hopefully to take it back to where it was even in the late 1970s. That seems to me to be a priority in education that must loom large in 1986.

I would not like to finish on the topic of money because I consider that, whilst money is absolutely necessary, it is not the only element. As I have already pointed out in the first part of my speech, I believe that social attitudes to education are probably far more important. If I might link the two together at this point, it is social attitudes to education which provide the political wherewithal to get a reasonable education budget out of whatever government happens to be in power. The Minister for Education (Senator Ryan), who is at the table, presumably knows that all to well. In the arguments that go on between the various departments on the various priorities that present themselves to government, education can assume a top priority only if it is a top priority within the community at large. If the community at large does not view the education of its youth as important, then doubtless the Government will not fund it as important.

I think that in the end it is important to get away from the rather odd notion that seems to have crept into the debate in recent years in that we see the result of education as being the credentials that apply to our children who leave primary and secondary school and to our young people who leave tertiary institutions. In other words, we attach the value of education to the degree or diploma or whatever else the person receives. Essentially I believe that value of education must be attached to the value of learning itself, what that gives the individual and what the individual is then able to give to the community because of his learning. Let us not fall back into that way of thinking which has sometimes crept into statements made by Prime Ministers over the past few years and which seems to suggest fairly clearly that the value of education is in those types of credentials. The value of education is a community value. A person's individual education undoubtedly will provide that person with a better chance in life and will also provide the community with a better future.

It is interesting to note the standing of teachers as revealed in a recent gallup poll. It rated them highly for honesty and professional ethics at 54 per cent. There were some categories higher than the teachers, but I am interested in those that were lower. Among them were Federal politicians, who were rated at 13 per cent, and journalists, who were rated at 11 per cent. It seems to me that it might be about time that those politicians and journalists who in 1985 have engaged in an unceasing denigration of teachers might better look at themselves because presumably they might be the people who need a lot more work done with them than the teachers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985 and five other education Bills. Senator Macklin, who is the only speaker in this debate for the Australian Democrats, chose not to mention any of the six Bills but to speak at a tangent in a rambling fashion about education generally. He spoke about the Sheridan articles which appeared in the Australian earlier this year on the Quality of Education Review Committee, on retention rates, on post-war years of underfunding and on the Government's Priority One youth campaign. I am surprised that the Democrats have not applied themselves to the details of the six Bills that are before us. These six education measures appropriate more than $2 billion of taxpayers' money and not only appropriate it in the usual forms to schools and tertiary education institutions. These measures also amount to a cut in the participation and equity program, which has been halved, and a $30m cut in technical and further education. Also, there has been a new departure, which the Opposition has welcomed in a bipartisan approach with the Government, on nurse education through colleges of advanced education. In particular, in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill there has been a radical departure from policy on the funding of new non-government schools and the expansion of these schools.

SPEECH.PARA: My colleague Senator Peter Baume has referred to five of the Bills already and in order to save the time of the Senate I concur with all that he has said. In my remarks I wish to discuss for the first time on the Opposition side the provisions in the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill for the funding of new non-government schools. Let us recognise from the outset that this Bill is not in the usual form of the past 10 years because the Hawke Government has chosen to put down an eight-year program for schools funding in Australia. The standing legislation in this matter has committed four years-half of that eight-year program. The legislation before us, which is in this form for the first time, will amend that standing legislation to provide updated schedules of funding for all the different programs that relate to schools. In this respect the financial impact of this Bill appropriates $1,495m for these school programs in 1986. This appropriation is a real reduction in overall schools expenditure of 1.3 per cent. It is a real reduction in program expenditure on government schools of 2.7 per cent and it is a real reduction in joint government and non-government schools programs of 3.3 per cent. In particular, it is a $20m reduction in the capital grants program for government and non-government schools. The main objection that the Opposition has to this measure is that it is linked with an elaborate mechanism which is, in fact, the implementation of the Connors report-the report of the Commonwealth Schools Commission Panel on Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools. It is these cutbacks, particularly in capital grants, that we oppose so vehemently. In those terms we have moved a second reading amendment, as Senator Baume has outlined, and we will continue to move amendments during the Committee stage. In fact, half the Bill is taken up with measures that implement the Connors report.

Let us put into some context the role of non-government schools in Australia. The fact is that 25 per cent of Australia's children attend non-government schools. We in the Opposition believe that there should be the greatest freedom of choice for parents between government and non-government schools. We want to make sure that there is good provision of education for the 75 per cent who choose government schools and equally good provision for the 25 per cent who choose non-government schools. At the moment $1 billion of recurrent money is saved to the taxpayer because 25 per cent of our children attend non-government schools. If these children all changed their enrolment to government schools the taxpayer would be required to come up with an additional $1 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —How do you arrive at that figure?

—That figure is based on the fact that in 1982-83 alone $818m was saved to the taxpayer because only a proportion of the cost of a government school place was received in respect of non-government school students. The grants from the States and the Commonwealth, when added together, amount to proportions varying between 25 per cent and 70 per cent of the cost of a government school place. There is a reduced commitment in relation to every enrolment in a non-government school. If $818m is the figure for 1982-83, given the rate of inflation and the cuts, that figure will be more like $1 billion in this current financial year. When the present Government was first elected in 1983-I will not be tedious; I will try to be very brief in going over the 1983 record-there was an attempt by the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) directly to attack non-government schools. There was a so-called hit list of non-government schools that would receive no funds from the Commonwealth for attendance by their students. There were meetings all over the country at which people protested this abolition of the concept of the basic grant and at the same time they protested the abolition of the percentage link between the subsidy given to non-government schools and that which is received by government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: As a result not only of the work of members of the Opposition in this Parliament and of the mass meetings around the country but also of back benchers within the Government parties, worried about their marginal seats, we urged the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to act. In 1984 the Prime Minister stepped in, and defeated this direct attack by putting down the eight-year plan. He said: `Be assured that you will have eight years of defined levels of funding for the 12 school levels'. So much for the initial response to the direct attack. What we have now in this legislation is the second approach by Senator Ryan and the Labor Government-what I call the indirect attack-to place in this legislation machinery that will stop capital grants going to new non-government schools, that will stop recurrent grants going to new non-government schools and expanded places in those new non-government schools and also have a mechanism for limiting those schools--

TALK.START.PARA: —You just said all of them.

—I will come to that now. Instead of the 12 levels that the Prime Minister's eight-year plan envisaged we now have 13 levels. There is an additional one from 1986 on for the first time. Some students enrolled in non-government schools will receive no recurrent grants per capita in respect of their enrolment if they do not meet several barriers or requirements that are spelt out.
—Criteria.

—The Minister chooses to call those requirements criteria. What are the 10 requirements or criteria that the Minister refers to? They can be summarised in this way: First of all, a school must give two years notice of its introduction of an expansion or on becoming a new school. Secondly, a school must be registered by the State. Thirdly, it must meet the minimum enrolment guidelines. Fourthly, it must be financially viable. Fifthly, it must give notice to education authorities in the region of the school and, subject to their views, it should not be in conflict with other plans for the expansion of government and non-government schools. Sixthly, it must fit into the projected characteristics of the locality concerned and its provision for education. Seventhly, a proposed new school must be of such priority that it be given funding by the Commonwealth. Eighthly, a school must then continue without significant change in its structure, purpose, the number of students, its location or the range or levels of studies. If there are any changes in these respects the Minister by this legislation may intervene and deny recurrent funding. Ninthly, a school must maintain an adequate level of funding from private sources. Tenthly, a school must not be excessive in increasing fees and charges.

SPEECH.PARA: All these ten requirements are set out in the legislation. A number of the early requirements are called initial criteria. Other requirements in this legislation are set out for systemic schools and non-systemic schools. It is my contention and that of the Opposition that, firstly, by this machinery-implementation of the Connors report-the Minister has the means to deny capital grants to newly established non-government schools or expansions of those schools. Secondly, it also has the machinery, for the first time, to deny any per capita grant to those students who do not meet this criteria in any expansion of a school or in any new school. Thirdly, these 10 rules, particularly the last two, give machinery to the Minister to shift a school's level of funding from, say, level six up to level four, or from level five up to level two, and so reduce the per capita grant that may go to a school.

In contrast with these 10 requirements that the Minister is defending that the Government has placed in this legislation, it is the Opposition's approach that there be one condition; that is, the one that Senator Colston referred to a moment ago-the registration of a school by a State. If a school is initiated by parents or by a community we believe that it needs to be able to be registered by the State as an approved education institution. With regard to all other matters-whether it is financially viable, whether it is in the right location, whether it is the right size or structure and whether it has the right fee level or will change fees up or down-these are entirely matters for that school to determine. Some of those matters may be relevant if a school wishes to gain more than the basic grant or it wishes to receive some needs-based supplement to the basic grant. Under a Liberal-National Party government there will not be this interfering or intervening legislation that will require that a new non-government school has to meet 10 requirements before it might gain some support from the Commonwealth. An enormous contrast is again demonstrated between the Government's and the Opposition's policies in this respect.

I point out that, if a school fails to follow just one of these 10 requirements, it can be denied Commonwealth financial support by this legislation. If a school trespasses on one of the first eight of the 10 requirements that I have outlined in this legislation, there would be no capital or recurrent funding. If a school transgresses one of the last two of the 10 requirements, it will have reduced recurrent funding. I believe that this is outrageous legislation and the Opposition regards it as outrageous legislation.

When the Connors Committee was set up, using guidelines in a letter sent by the Minister to the Schools Commission in October 1984, it was in the mind of the Prime Minister a couple of months prior to a Federal election. This Connors inquiry was instituted at the same time as the Prime Minister's eight years of guaranteed recurrent funding to schools and it was left as something to be dealt with after the election. The Connors Committee reported in February and the Minister tabled the report in March. At the same time that the Minister tabled the report-there was no ability for anyone in Australia to be consulted about the Government's response to the Connors Committee findings-the Minister made an announcement to the effect that the Government had totally accepted the Connors report.

We now have before us, in December, legislation embodying all the findings and conclusions in the Connors report. When the implementing legislation came before the House of Representatives in mid-November it was a matter of a few days before it was then debated. At that time the Connors report was not available in Government bookshops. There still has not been any Press analysis and discussion of the legislation. When this legislation was debated in the House of Representatives it was given one and a half hours-between 10.30 p.m. and midnight on 20 November-and something like five members spoke in the debate. It was vehemently opposed by the shadow Minister for Education and Youth Affairs, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack). There have been complaints about the time given to debate at a late hour important legislation which is based on a radical and sharp change in the Government's policy on non-government schools. The Senate is now in the final week of its sittings and time restrictions have been placed on debate.

Beginning in 1986 and for all the years thereafter this legislation sets out the criteria on which any new non-government school or extension of a non-government school will be judged. That judgment is based on the 10 odious requirements that are set out in the Connors report and are now implemented in this legislation. In October this year the Minister announced that some 68 new non-government schools would receive capital funding. In fact, 37 of these were existing schools. Although the majority were not fully new, they are new in the new education-speak of the legislation which redefines a new non-government school, or an extension to a government school, in terms of a change of location or in terms of a change in structure-for instance, a boarding school becoming a non-boarding school; a single sex school becoming a mixed school; two schools amalgamating; or a school going to a new level of education by, for instance, adding on a secondary school to its primary base.

These new departures have led to 37 of the 68 schools funded this year to be described as new non-government schools. In fact, 31 of them were entirely new and they received that part of the capital funding which was able to escape the $20m cut this financial year. Twenty-one new schools were in fact denied any support at all. So of the 52 schools that were in fact new, 40 per cent were denied any capital funding-that is, 21 schools out of 52, a 40 per cent failure rate on the criteria that is set in this legislation.

Moreover, this legislation was acted upon by the Minister prior to its being debated in the Parliament. The Minister may argue that the Government's policy was clear from the time of the March declaration that the Connors report would be fully implemented but it is not in fact the law of the land. If we had been able to persuade the Australian Democrats to take a greater interest in this legislation and to agree to our amendments, we would have amended this legislation. The Minister would have had to write to all of the schools to say that the decisions do not apply.

I believe that a 40 per cent failure rate is only the beginning of a trend of denying capital money to new non-government schools. But not only capital money is being denied. From 1986 unsuccessful new non-government schools will also be denied recurrent funds in respect of students they enrol. I think this is disgraceful. As I say, it adds a thirteenth level to the 12 levels that the Prime Minister so reassuringly announced to Australian schools. He gave an assurance before the last election that all of the schools would be receiving a per capita grant. That is not the case any more. It is no surprise that as schools are learning about this outcome they are protesting vigorously. To save the time of the Senate, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard two letters, one from the Australian Parents Council and the other from the Victorian Parents Council.
Leave granted.
The documents read as follows-

Dear Senator,

The Victorian Parents Council, representing 100,000 non-government schoolchildren and their parents, is outraged that, at midnight on 20th November, the Government pushed through the House of Representatives the State Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill 1985, allowing no time for informed debate. The Government's use of the ``guillotine'' to stifle debate is an affront to all Australian citizens.

We are disgusted that the Hawke Government has seen fit to write into legislation the power for the Minister for Education, Senator Ryan, to breach the undertaking given to non-government school communities in the 1984 School Commission Guidelines that all children in all non-govenment schools will receive a minimum Federal recurrent grant.
The right of every non-government schoolchild to a basic recurrent grant from government is a fundamental principle of the Victorian Parents Council.

The definition of new non-government schools incorporated in the legislation is quite dishonest as non-government schools already operating cannot in truth be called ``new'' schools just because Senator Ryan has sanctioned a formula which says they are ``new''. They should be properly described as established schools which, together with new non-government schools, are endeavouring to meet the enourmous demands from Australian parents for non-government schooling.

The Victorian Parents Council regards this Bill as a blatant attack on the prior right of parents to choose the kind of education that shall be given to their children and the right of all Australian children to just and equitable treatment by Government in the distribution of public funds.

TALK.START.PARA: —These letters speak for themselves. However, it is clear from the reply by the Minister's Assistant Private Secretary that although this school met all the criteria-the letter reassures the school that it was in the right location, it was financially viable, it was well planned, it fitted in with the educational needs of the community of which it is a part and it was not duplicating government or non-government schools-it was denied capital funding and has not received one dollar of capital assistance during the period of the present Government purely on the ground that it did not have high enough priority as a result of a $20m cut in capital provision for non-government schools. This school, which was established as a result of an enormous commitment by parents, is one of 46 schools which make up the National Union of Associations for Christian Parent- controlled Schools.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an explicit criterion in the legislation that a school must be of sufficient priority-the emphasis is on the word `priority'-to be accorded Commonwealth financial support. The Minister under this legislation has the mechanism by which to make inadequate provisions in the capital area. As a result we find that this year only 60 per cent of new applications could be approved. What is to happen next year? It is always in the hands of a government to determine the Budget and to make such provisions. But what happens if all of the non-government school proprosals around Australia are developed conscientiously, planned carefully and meet all the criteria? What if they meet all of what I would call the nine unnecessary and even odious criteria and then in the end find that they are not considered to be of sufficient priority, given the low provision of capital funds by the Government? The Government can deny schools which otherwise conform with worthy concepts such as need, priority, accountability and planning. These criteria reflect all of these good concepts and the Opposition has no argument with proper planning, proper accountability or priority of need. But we believe that those words are used to defend this kind of legislation in an inappropriate and disgraceful way. The Opposition opposes the way in which those good concepts and words have been used as an excuse for the high handed action that has been taken in this case.

I ask the Minister why it is that a school such as the Torrens Valley Christian School should not be granted capital and recurrent funding. Finally, I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a table of schools which, together with the Torrens Valley Christian School, belong to the National Union of Associations for Christian Parent-controlled Schools.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have not sighted it. What is the source of it?
—It is a tabulated summary of school information produced by the National Union of Associations for Christian Parent-controlled Schools. I will give it to the Minister to examine.
—I want to look at it first.

—The list shows that, of the 46 schools in this Association alone-and they represent perhaps only one quarter of the new non-government schools that have developed since 1980-only 18 have progressed into secondary classes. This legislation will deny the majority of these schools the same fair chance to extend themselves into secondary levels as they expected when they set out. Why should these primary schools be denied their original intention to extend into years 7, 8, 9, 10, 11 and 12? Why should not similar schools be able to live up to their original intentions, to meet the desires of their enrolled students and the communities they serve?

SPEECH.PARA: I can only say that in this repect the Opposition is diametrically opposed to the Government. We will not support the parts of the legislation which place these objectionable criteria as barriers to the freedom of choice of Australian parents with regard to schools. We will oppose those matters at the Committee stage and we will seek the Senate's approval for the amendment that we have moved to the second reading motion. I seek leave for the incorporation of the table in Hansard.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is leave granted?

—I and my officers have looked at it. I really cannot agree to its incorporation. It is a very long and complex table. I am advised by the Senate officers that Hansard would have a great deal of difficulty in reproducing it, if it could. At this stage we have no way of substantiating the figures in it. Senator Teague has already put on the record the major points he is making about it so at this stage I am unable to agree to that.
—I will read it into the record at the Committee stage to make sure that it is in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zakharov Sen A.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will speak very briefly in this cognate debate, not because there is not a great deal that I would like to say in support of these Bills but because time is very short and the listening public should be aware of this. The lack of speeches from Government senators on this and many other Bills that we have before us this week in no way indicates a lack of or even lukewarm support for those Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I therefore intend to confine my remarks to one of the Bills, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill, about which Senator Teague has been speaking at some length. This Bill covers four matters: Adjustments to funding to allow for increases in price levels, provision for the extension of annual program allocations to 1986, provision for the transfer of certain special education responsibilities from the Department of Community Services to the Commonwealth Schools Commission-that is something that meets a long-felt need-and provision for the implementation of the Government's policy on new non-government schools.

I wish to address my remarks mainly to the last aspect and the response it has brought from some quarters and groups in the community representing some sections of the non-government school sector which have vehemently opposed the Government's policy in this sector from the outset and which continue to oppose it against all ideals of equity. The funding policy now being implemented was developed in full consultation with both the government and the non-government sector. In fact, some of us on the Government side were critical of the Schools Commission consultation process in early 1984, when the Commission travelled around the States, because it seemed to give more time listening to the non-government sector than to the government sector. Those consultations have continued and I understand are continuing.

The recommendations of the Schools Commission and the Government's response to them have been available for some months. During that time I have certainly received material from the same bodies as has Senator Teague-the Australian Parents Council and the Victorian Parents Council-often misrepresenting the historical facts of the case and the Government's position on the proposals embodied in this legislation. But I have not been approached, and I think this is significant, by individual schools or parents in my State, which I would have expected had there been widespread dissatisfaction as my interest in and experience in education is well known. I think I am the only Victorian senator who has a professional background in education. So I would have thought that, had there been dissatisfaction, as there has been sometimes on previous occasions, I would have heard about it.

TALK.START.PARA: —But even those representations came on 28 November. The Australian Parents Council was only as recent as 28 November.

—Certainly, I agree, but I have read the material and I do not give it any credence. I believe that some staff bodies in the non-government sector have in fact welcomed increased accountability, as indeed have some parents who are well aware that in some non-government schools there has been in the past little accountability for spending, even to their own school communities.

SPEECH.PARA: Before going on to discuss the need for accountability in this as in all areas of government spending, I make the point that the non-government sector also benefits from funding on special programs, including programs to meet special needs. I remember that in the debate in the House of Representatives that was a point which was certainly distorted by the Opposition. Indeed, this very legislation provides for funding for special education projects in non-government as well as government schools. That is set out in the Schedule at the back of the Bill.

I am genuinely surprised, although I have grown more cynical over the last three years that I have been in the Senate, that the Opposition is so upset about accountability in this area of government expenditure when it is so anxious to track down what it sees as misspent expenditure on social security or even, as was the case last week, on the printing of a government report. As the Minister, Senator Ryan, noted in Question Time yesterday, the same senators who spend days assiduously seeking accountability from departments and from the Government during the examination of the Estimates are now complaining that the Government is asking the non-government schools to account for their large sums of taxpayers' money-an increase this year alone of $12m.

I do not believe that the information being sought is intrusive. Indeed, it is much less intrusive than information sought, for example, about the living arrangements of a supporting parent beneficiary. I would expect that most schools would be perfectly willing to supply this information, which should be readily available if the school is accountable to its own community, including its parents and its staff, as it surely should be. Accountability is not just an end in itself. It is also a check on how public money is spent. But it is essential also to proper educational planning.

Schools have been established in the years since the Schools Commission was set up, schools which clearly were not viable. An example, and there are many of them, in my State is a relatively new school whose total enrolments rapidly fell below 20 before it finally closed. When this happens there is a loss to the parents as well as to the Government but, more importantly, there is disruption to the education of the students concerned, particularly as in this case they were primary school students in a country area. In other cases new schools have threatened the viablity of existing schools in their area. There needs to be greater accountability than this legislation provides and in broader areas than the financial one.

I find it anomalous at the very least that the Government is providing funds in some cases to schools whose educational practices are working against the achievement of Government policies. For example, schools which teach, supposedly with a biblical justification, that females are necessarily subordinate to males must surely run counter to the aims of equal opportunity and anti-sex discrimination policies. I have said it before in debates on education, and I will continue to say it while there is a need, that the States have a responsibility in the area of quality of education which they are not always meeting. The Government is funding schools which I believe carry out an educational program and use educational practices which are in fact anti-educational. At some of these are schools which include the word `Christian' in their name-this should concern all Christians-children spend long periods of the day receiving programmed instruction of very doubtful value based on literal interpretation of the Bible, often supervised by untrained staff, with little opportunity for discussion and none for the development of a critical attitude to what is presented to them.

This is not education as it should be available in a democratic society. I urge registration authorities in the States to look more closely at educational accountability. I have concentrated on one part of one Bill because this is the one that the Opposition seeks to change. But I certainly commend all the Bills for their contribution to quality and equity in education at all levels.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will spend the majority of my time discussing the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1985 because this is certainly the most contentious of the Bills in this cognate debate tonight. This amendment Bill implements many of the recommendations of the Connors report on Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools. I believe it will create a number of problems for independent schools if it is passed unamended. The legislation virtually gives the Minister the power to deny Federal recurrent grants to children in some new or expanded non-government schools. This Bill also incorporates the bogus definition of `new' schools; that is, schools which change location, add new levels of schooling, amalgamate, separate, or change their status to single sex or co-educational schools, boarding schools or day schools. These grants could be refused if a school expanded its operation in any area which is classified as being already adequately served by non-government schools.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has reneged on its promise of August 1984 in its guidelines to the Commonwealth Schools Commission that all non-government schools would continue to be eligible for assistance. The Connors report defines a new school as one coming into existence or one having a change which results in a significant increase or a change in clientele, therefore giving the possibility of a number of schools amalgamating. I refer, for example, to a Catholic boys or girls school combining their higher school certificate campuses for the greater benefit and advantage of their students, or otherwise upgrading their services. Such a school technically could lose its funding or at least be denied funding for any extra places. There is the possibility that not enough funding would be given to new non-govenment schools or that some schools would not be given any funding at all. This is because the recurrent funding for the funding of students and teaching places is at present a necessary pre-condition for eligibility for capital grants.

By this expedient measure of denying recurrent funding to new non-government schools, or an existing school seeking to expand its activities, the Government will be able to relieve itself of the need to consider such a school for capital grants. Therefore, the recommendations of the Connors report, as implemented in this Bill, strike at the very heart of independent schools and threaten to deprive parents of the basic right to choose the kind of eduction that they want their children to receive. I think this question must be asked: Why are so many non-government schools being set up? Surely, it is because of a dissatisfaction with the government system. There is also the question as to whether this system of regulation of schools is best left to the State level rather than the Commonwealth level. So the development of new non-government schools will be controlled by fiscal means. Until now Commonwealth recurrent grants were paid automatically to all non-government schools which were granted State or Territory registration. But under the scheme proposed in this Bill the Commnwealth Government will decide which new non-government schools will be approved for the purposes of recurrent funding. I believe that this legislation will make it more difficult for small schools, especially non-Catholic schools, to be established.

The new planning guidelines will incorporate existing constraints requiring two years notice, minimum enrolments of at least 20 in a primary school or 70 in a secondary school and documented proof of financial viability. Indeed, these are very high standards for small groups seeking to establish a school in the future. They will be required to prove that there will not be an adverse effect on schools in the same area before they are eligible for Commonwealth support.

While the Opposition acknowledges that planning is essential and that resources must be allocated for the best effect, we are worried that the Connors report recommendations, the so-called planned educational provision having regard to such factors as rationalisation of educational services and facilities in an area, could be used to reinforce the Government's bias against non-government schools which has already been revealed in the Budget allocations. This is worrying because we can see that more and more parents are choosing to enrol their children in non-government schools; the numbers of enrolments in non-government schools have increased by 17 per cent in the last decade, while enrolments in government schools have grown by only 3 per cent. Catholic education authorities have accepted the principle of planned educational provisions. They have stated they would find it unacceptable if the Government could restrict, by a Budget limit alone, the number of students in new non-government schools. The proposals in this Bill have been attacked by the Australian Parents Council because they will increase the controls which will make planning for new non-government schools a nightmare for non-government school authorities.

The Opposition does not oppose the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 3). The Government claims that this Bill supports extra tertiary education places. The fact is that at the moment we have an inadequate number of places. In 1983-84, 56,000 students did not receive an offer from the university or college which they were interested in attending. This sort of measure, I believe, will not make much of an impact on this sort of waiting list. The Government will soon be creating a second access route for overseas students; yet Australian students are still competing within quotas against fellow Australians on scholarships and private overseas students. I refer to the creation of full cost recovery in regard to overseas students who have been denied entrance to institutions. If overseas students were placed totally outside the quota, as is recommended in the report of the Jackson Committee to Review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, and the overseas aid component were made explicit, some places at least would be available to Australian students.

Again, the recommendations of the report of the Jackson Committee, if implemented, would have balanced our international aid component and our responsibility to prospective university students in Australia. The presence of overseas students on our university and college campuses, unfortunately, has become a politically sensitive issue over the last few years. Because budgetary constraints have imposed limitations on tertiary entry, many capable students are denied entry to degree and diploma courses each year. Unfortunately, many of those who have been unsuccessful in gaining a university place often feel that overseas students have benefited at their expense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —The best thing that could be said about this debate, I suppose, is that time constraints have been imposed on all senators. I will oblige by restricting my comments, although I would have liked to talk in particular about the measure which deals with tertiary education. However, it appears that the Senate will divide on the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill 1985, particularly the question relating to the new procedures that have been established by this legislation for so-called accountability for independent schools.

SPEECH.PARA: My first comment is that it would be best if this particular measure were deferred. After all, the Connors report on Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools came before the Parliament only in March and then there was a follow-up statement in October, I think on 15 October. Of course, the measure that is before us takes that one step further. I believe this measure does go further than simply addressing the question of financial accountability. The Minister or the bureaucracy is able to intrude into the affairs of non-government schools and thus affront the rights of parents of students attending non-government schools. Details of enrolment policies, information on policy-making structures and statements on educational objectives are all to be provided by the schools. The definition of a new school, incorporating as it does a bar on expansions of existing schools, I believe should create grave concern. It certainly goes far deeper than the question of accountability. I believe that the effect would be to restrict the number of children able to attend non-government schools if that were the parental choice. It is disconcerting if accountability is to be equated with servility, particularly if this servility is to be imposed upon the independent schools system in respect of having its curricula conform to the social objectives of whatever government is in power or whatever Minister happens to control the education portfolio. I believe that matter should be clarified.

I have not spoken on these measures for the last 12 or 15 months, since they became matters of very great concern to a large number of parents throughout the length and breadth of Australia. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), after a series of meetings, gave some guarantees. The measures that are currently before us may be seen by parents and, indeed-I emphasise this-by some systemic schools, as undermining the undertakings that were given by the Prime Minister. I believe the Government will probably hear more about this matter. It is a question which will be with us for some considerable time. I do not know what the haste is to proceed with these parts of the Bills. After all, they attempt to establish the guidelines from now until 1990. I consider that it would have been better for the Government not to have incorporated these measures in this Bill but to have allowed further debate and discussion with both the systemic schools and the various representatives of the parents before incorporating the measures into legislation. The legislation passed through the House of Representatives at midnight one night. There was very little debate on it. It was part of the legislation that was guillotined.

TALK.START.PARA: —They never debate anything down there.

—If they have a chance, they do. I have actually heard them debate one or two matters down there. However, on this occasion they did not have a chance to debate fully this measure. I consider that the Minister should be prepared, once representations have been made to her, to come back with suggestions, further refinements and amendments, as required, to ensure the true independence and freedom of choice of parents in this very vital area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —There has been a quite lengthy debate on the six education Bills which are before the Senate this evening. Substantially, the Bills have been supported by all sides of the chamber. Measures such as the supplementary funding of tertiary education which, together with the Government's other policies, will achieve an increase in the vicinity of 28,000 new places in higher education, have been approved. The legislation enabling the funding of college of advanced education based nurse education has been generally supported. Other measures concerning the capacity of institutions to take in extra overseas students on a full cost basis also have been endorsed.

SPEECH.PARA: All honourable senators are aware that we are under time constraints. Whilst I would very much like to expound the benefits of the six Bills before us tonight, I will not take the opportunity to do so because other opportunities will present themselves. The one aspect of the legislative package which has been opposed by the Opposition concerns the new criteria for the approval of new non-government schools. I understand that there is to be some discussion about this matter during the Committee stage. However, I simply say this: Senator Teague's contribution was, unfortunately, rather confused. He seemed to be suffering a very fundamental confusion in regard to the difference between capital and recurrent funding.

I remind the Senate that approval of new non-government schools for recurrent funding by the Commonwealth is granted according to a report by Lindsay Connors, the Commonwealth Schools Commissioner, and brought down by a panel of commissioners. The non-government schools representatives have a majority on the panel and there was absolutely extensive consultation with non-government parent organisations, non-government school authorities, non-government teachers, and also, of course, with State education authorities who are, naturally, vitally concerned with the development of non-governmental schools in their States, teachers and parents. It was a very extensive consultation process. After I received the report on behalf of the Government I had further consultations with major non-government school groups and with the Prime Minister. So any suggestion that there was not adequate consultation and discussion about this report is quite wrong. I would say that it was one of the most extensively discussed new policies ever brought in by a Commonwealth government in the education area.

All non-government authorities support the idea of the proper planning of new non-government schools. The reason is that those of them who have experience in the development of the administration of schools know that unplanned developments can be very bad for educational opportunities for the children who may go into schools which subsequently collapse. Unplanned developments can have a very deleterious effect, as I think Senator Zakharov pointed out very lucidly-even though she was under constraints of time, too-on existing commitments that already have been made by State governments, parents and non-government schools authorities to government and non-government schools. It is simply irresponsible and very inexperienced to suggest that any group that wants to establish a school anywhere, regardless of financial and other commitments that already have been made, should be funded. That is not our policy and it has never been our policy.

To conclude this stage of the debate, I say that the fact that 68 new schools have been approved by the Government is a demonstration that our policy is one of planned, fair and equitable growth. If honourable senators addressed themselves to the range of schools that have been approved amongst the 68, I think they would find nothing to criticise in terms of the capacity of parents to exercise choice within reasonable parameters of responsible planning under our policies. A very large variety of religious schools-schools based on major religions and minor religions-have been funded and schools based on non-religious but other educational philosophies, such as the Rudolf Steiner and Montessori schools, have been funded. Very small schools have been funded. Large, conventional schools have been funded. Single sex schools, co-educational schools-in fact, virtually every type of school that exists in our extremely diverse system-have been able to attract funding.

Not all applications were successful, but those applicants which were not successful have rights of appeal. The applications were assessed not by bureaucrats, as has been charged by Mr Shack, or by politicians until there was final advice, but by representative committees where non-government schools authorities and State authorities worked together to make the best decisions as they saw them in terms of the needs of a particular State or area. I commend the Bills to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some questions with regard to clause 6. I ask the Minister why the date of 15 October 1984 is mentioned in the Bill that is before us. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —This might be the appropriate stage to ask a question because it refers to the application of those criteria. I did inform the Minister's office that I would like to discuss an example of a school which has been denied funding to give the Minister an opportunity to detail more than has been detailed to date in the debate of how precisely a school might be denied funding when, on the surface, it certainly seems to be a reasonably acceptable case for funding. This school is in an area where there is a demand for education following the Rudolf Steiner philosophy. There does appear on the surface at least to be reasonable growth in the local area. If one looks at the enrolments in public schools one will see that in the last four years there has been an average growth of 15 per cent. The Connors report on Planning and Funding Policies for New Non-government Schools mentioned that the figure of 2 per cent had been canvassed. That would seem to fit into that particular criterion. SPEECH.PARA: I would also be particularly interested in how the interim committee-the Minister might like to comment on that committee with its three non-government school representatives out of six committee members-collects the detailed information on the various criteria set out in these clauses.
