SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will answer the last part of Senator Macklin's question first. It is an answer that I have given to several members of parliament and senators who have come lobbying on behalf of particular school proposals. The first and most important answer is that a school whose proposal was not accepted by its State committee and which was not recommended by the Commonwealth Schools Commission for funding has the opportunity to appeal against that decision. In order to appeal against that decision it should go back to the Schools Commission. The Commission, in co-operation with the State committee, will advise the school what additional information it seeks.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to state as a matter of guidance to senators who are interested in particular schools that it is not appropriate for senators to rush off and immediately lobby me-the Minister-as to why a school did not get funding or what is going to happen to that school when that school has not gone through the proper appeals procedures. Appeals procedures are laid down. An appeals committee has been set up precisely for this purpose. Schools have been advised of this and I am a little bemused when schools choose not to follow the established procedure, about which they have been carefully advised by the Schools Commission, but choose instead to go the route of political lobbying. I do not make any decision on information other than information that comes forth to me through the appropriate channels. Therefore, the best thing that school can do is the same as any other school which feels that it has additional information which may result in a more favourable assessment of its proposal-it should go through those channels again. They were advised of this from the start and they were advised by letter when they were advised that their proposals were not agreed to. They were advised straight away that they had the opportunity to appeal and they were advised how to consult the Schools Commission to find out what additional information they needed to give.

I do not have the precise information relating to the particular school referred to by Senator Macklin. It has not yet come to me by way of appeal. Under the new policy there is a decentralisation of decision-making to some extent so that the representative State committees get the information regarding the particular projects and assess it according to the criteria laid down by the Government. Because of the time frame involved, unless there are some very obvious reasons for questioning the judgment of State committees, the judgment of State committees was accepted.

I think Senator Macklin would understand that if one is going to delegate and decentralise decision making it does not make any sense to second guess all of the decisions made by those State committees. They are representative committees and, of course, as a very important part of the whole process, they have on them representatives of the State governments. One of the very important features of the new procedures is that the State governments, which have the responsibility for their own school systems, are very much involved in the planning process because it is quite often the case that it is State schools which are disadvantaged if unplanned new non-government schools are allowed to develop in the vicinity of State schools with declining enrolments. So given that those decisions were delegated, given that those State committees were representative and given that there were appeals procedures, I am generally confident about the nature of the advice coming from the State committees. My confidence is increased by the fact that any school that was not successful in that first round has been informed from the outset that it may appeal and what information it needs to conduct that appeal. I am not aware that the particular school that Senator Macklin is interested in has lodged an appeal, but if it believes that by providing further information it can be established that the school falls within the criteria, it ought to be busy appealing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for that. I assume that in circumstances such as this local, on the spot information would be provided by the State department or State department people. Is that the general way in which the program is working?

—Yes; the local information about existing school facilities, planned government developments in the area, demographic developments and so forth, would be provided by representatives of the State system, although the State committees, of course, have broad representation of the non-government systems which would also be providing their information along those lines.

—In view of the answer given by the Minister a moment ago when she advised Senator Macklin that it was generally not appropriate for the Minister to interfere with the recommendations of the State committees, why did the Minister interfere with the recommendation of a State committee in relation to a school in the electorate of Lowe, a marginal Labor electorate?

—Senator Baume has asked this question before. I do not know how many times he wants the answer since he was given a very full answer at the time when the estimates for the Department of Education and the Schools Commission were being discussed. I will repeat the answer briefly: Further information came to me from the Catholic Education Office; that is, from the State body that has the responsibility for the administration of Catholic schools in New South Wales. It volunteered further information to the effect that the particular school would be able to attract an adequate number of students to justify a further development without detracting from other schools in the area because it was offering a particular service not being offered by other schools in the area; namely, it was a single sex girls school planning to offer single sex girls classes in years 11 and 12. That information was taken into account by me when the decision was made.

—When the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) was summing up in the second reading debate she encouraged honourable senators to address themselves to the 68 schools that had gained approval for their capital grant applications in the last few months and, no doubt, the 21 schools that were unsuccessful. I ask the Minister whether a summary of the 68 successful schools and the 21 unsuccessful schools is available to honourable senators so that we may address ourselves to the range of schools that were successful and not successful.

—I certainly have some information on the schools that were not successful and I am willing to make what information I have available to the chamber. But I point out that the proponents of schools that were not successful may not be particularly enthusiastic about having the defects in their applications widely broadcast. I can give the honourable senator the list of those proposals. I will make it available.

—I take it that after this debate I will receive from the Minister a summary of those two lists. My question relates to clause 6 (7) on page 9 of the Bill. Is it correct that this sub-clause is entirely retrospective in that any application that has been received already, that related to 1986 or a subsequent year, is to be dealt with under terms set out in this Bill that are, in fact, quite different from those in sub-section 6 (3) of the principal Act under which it otherwise would have been considered?

—The criteria set out in clause 7 are the criteria that were applied in the assessment of proposals for 1986. When the Connors report on Planning the Funding Policies for New Non-Government Schools was accepted by us in March this year that was made quite clear.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, that is the case. Senator Teague ought to understand that the Government announced its new policy in March this year and schools were advised accordingly. TALK.START.PARA: —In the summation the Minister brought to the second reading debate she referred to what she called a confusion in my speech between a capital grant application and recurrent funding on a per capita basis to a school in respect of students enrolled in the school. Under clause 7 of the Bill before us, is it not the case that the Minister, expressly by this proposed new sub-section, has the power to specify a maximum number of students in respect of any school receiving recurrent funding; indeed, to alter a maximum to another maximum; or, where there is not a maximum specified, to introduce a maximum? I put it to the Minister that I was not seeking to confuse the Senate or the Minister; I was wanting to make it crystal clear that, for the first time, in 1986 there will be some schools that do not receive a per capital recurrent grant in respect of all the students enrolled in the school. That is, if the Minister by this power declares a maximum number of students then those enrolments beyond that maximum number will not receive a recurrent grant.

—The Minister does not declare a maximum. The school applies for increased enrolment to a certain number. If that is a large change, then that school comes within the provisions of this new part of the Bill. The school seeks approval for a certain number. The school itself puts forward the number of students it wants to have. Once that is approved as part of a planned expansion, then the school attracts recurrent funding for that number of students, but not beyond.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand that part. Let me read from page 10 of the Bill:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . the Minister may, by determination in writing, vary the list of systemic schools by-
going to paragraph (c)-
specifying a maximum number of students.

It is certainly the case that a school may apply for a maximum to be declared or to be varied, but it is the power of the Minister, according to this Bill, that will determine the matter. The Minister will say `having heard your submission, I declare that your maximum is confirmed according to your application', or that it is not. Is it the case that if the Minister does not approve the criteria, for any one of the reasons set out in the Bill, a maximum would be set and that if the school enrols students beyond that maximum, it would not receive recurrent per capita funding in respect of those enrolments beyond the maximum? Is that not so?

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Teague seems to be grappling with some of the basic concepts of the Westminster system. At a certain point the Minister has to approve all expenditures, and the legislation reflects this. Perhaps Senator Peter Baume could instruct his colleague as to the nature of the Westminster system. When a school seeks expansion, it does so by the procedures laid down here. When the Commission advises me that that is in order, then, yes, I approve payment of recurrent grants for that maximum. The purpose of this kind of planning provision is to ensure that a school does not suddenly change its enrolment from 200 to 2,000 without going through appropriate planning procedures. Once those procedures are gone through, approved and agreed to, the Minister has to agree to the funding. A Minister has to be responsible for all expenditures of money on behalf of the public.

—I thank the Minister. I am familiar with the Westminster system and the responsibility of Ministers. Let me give a concrete example. Let us say that a primary school has planned for some years to extend in 1986 to include in the school enrolments year 8 and year 9. Let us say that the school makes application for approval for a capital grant for the extra classrooms with respect to the year 8 and year 9 enrolments. At the same time it makes a second application that the maximum number to gain a per capita recurrent fund in respect of that school be increased to take account of the additional enrolments in year 8 and year 9. Let us say that for one reason or another the Minister denies the capital grant. Will this Bill give the Minister the power automatically to allow the increase in the maximum number of enrolments so that the school willy-nilly in respect of all its enrolments, including year 8 and year 9, will get a per capita grant?

—I must advise the honourable senator that the applications for capital grants are separate from the applications for recurrent grants. It is quite possible-it has happened on a number of occasions and will probably happen increasingly-for a school to get approval for a recurrent per capita grant for students. A school which has a high income and which is in a stable area or perhaps an area of declining enrolments may for various reasons get approval to expand numbers. Given that capital funds are finite and have to be allocated according to need and various other criteria, it may be successful in its application for an expansion of 500 students for recurrent purposes, and it then may proceed to make an application for capital but because capital is a finite amount it may not be successful. It is quite possible for a school to get recurrent per capita funding for a body of students but not to be successful in seeking a capital grant associated with that expansion.

—Does the Minister envisage that in the 1986 calendar year any school will be denied a maximum for the per capita grant that will at any time be less than the number of enrolled students for which it is seeking a per capita grant?

—If a school chose to enrol students beyond the agreed maximum, it would be putting itself in that position. We are not aware of any schools having done that. Most schools are responsible and understand the system. They are pretty much continually advised by the Commonwealth Schools Commission on how to proceed in these matters. So the schools achieve approval for a maximum enrolment of, say, 1,000 students and they get recurrent funding for that. If a school achieved an approval for a per capita enrolment of 1,000 students and then suddenly decided without any approval or consultation to add several hundred more students-this is a hypothetical case-it would be in difficulty with its recurrent funding for those extra students; it would have to come back--
—They would not get it.

—It may get it, but it would have to apply; it would have to go through the procedures again. If that growth were within the parameters laid down by this policy the school would get it; if it were not, it would not get it. As yet, we know of no schools having chosen to enrol students beyond their approved maximum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Clauses 7, leave out proposed new sections 6A and 6B.
(2) Clause 9, leave out proposed new sections 7A and 7B.

The Committee is considering clauses 7 and 9 together, by leave. These clauses put into effect the new Government policy for the funding of non-government schools, which has been the subject of some questions. The two clauses are almost identical, clause 9 putting into effect for non-systemic non-government schools what clause 7 puts into effect for systemic non-government schools. The Opposition's objections relate to matters of detail, some of which my colleague Senator Teague has raised, but they relate more to a disagreement concerning the threshold question of the principle which the Minister is seeking to enshrine. The Minister is seeking to have a planned provision of school funding. Her policy seeks to place at a high premium provision in a geographical area and the judging of new applications for schools against that provision. So one of the criteria will be whether or not a new school will adversely affect existing schools in a region. The criteria which will be built into the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act by virtue of this provision, if it is successful, include the changes which have been the subject of the exchange back and forth across the chamber in the last few minutes. For example, a school may wish to vary its number of students or it may wish to change from a single sex school to a co-educational school; it may wish to raise its level of educational offering and the number of streams it offers; or it may wish to relocate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Major changes.

—Major changes, in part or in whole. One of the criteria against which judgments are to be made is what the effect will be on the provision of other educational services in the region. This will produce a freeze, as it were, on educational innovation in the region. The Minister for Education shakes her head but it will tend to do that. One of the few ways that some parents can get what they want for their children today-immediately-if they are dissatisfied is to try to seek some alternative form of provision. The parents involved may wish to do this in a region where the level of provision of schooling is, according to the best estimates of the planners, totally adequate, but for the parents involved, it is not adequate. I will give honourable senators an example. The demographic picture in many parts of Sydney is changing rapidly. In some of the suburbs there has been a big influx of certain ethnic communities-for example, the Arabic speaking community in certain parts of southern Sydney. The level of educational provision in that region may be quite adequate in terms of public schooling but as a result of demographic changes there may be a desire to open up a new school, say an Arabic school. There may be a desire in some areas to open up a new Catholic school even though there is quite adequate provision of public education in that area. There may be a desire to open up a school which does not fit in with the total provision. The criteria which are laid down would mean that any such application would be given a lower priority because of the educational provision in that region.

SPEECH.PARA: There then comes a value question which must be determined, that is, whether the restriction of educational choice, as it were, to the existing schools, which may help the efficient use of resources and suit the planners, will provide parents with the kind of choice they feel is needed for their children today. Although I drew attention to the fact that the Minister intervened over a school in the Lowe electorate, I must point out that she was making a choice which met parental demand for extra educational choice, even though the State committee had made a judgment, based upon the criteria which are laid down here, that that school should get only a low priority.

We believe that the proposals will prevent and lessen innovation and choice in educational offerings. We believe that they will, in effect, move towards the provision of an educational cartel-and I use the words loosely-where those that are already in the field will remain there and will be protected because anyone else attempting to move in to make extra provision will find it difficult to get the approval that is wanted. If, in fact, parents are dissatisfied and they wish to start their own school, I believe that they should be able to attract the funding to do so. When their application has to be judged, as provided in the Bill, against the plans for future education, both government and non-government in the State and in that locality, it gives ample opportunity for those who are already running schools, whether they are government or non-government schools, in the State and in the locality, to put a spoke in their wheel because if a new school opens it may mean fewer enrolments in the existing schools. That may be a necessary precondition to improvement in the quality of education because there is no doubt that the movement of children from an existing school may have both good and bad effects. One of the good effects is that it may put that existing school on notice that it needs to re-examine its method of operation, its educational offerings and practices. The emergence of new schools helps to do that.

The Opposition believes that the changes in clauses 7 and 9 are unwelcome. The value position which the Government has taken is unfriendly to non-government schools and unfriendly to the wishes of parents in non-government schools. If a school wants to increase its numbers because enrolments are pouring in, we believe that it should be able to do so and that the subsidy which it attracts should be enrolment based rather than centrally planned. We do not think that central planning has been good for tertiary education and we do not think it will be good for the provision of non-government schooling. I go no further than that. I thank the Minister for having given leave for the amendments to be moved together. I commend the amendments to the Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The amendments moved by Senator Peter Baume are not acceptable to the Government and I think Senator Baume's explanation of why he moved them was a very clear and lucid exposition of the philosophical difference between his Party in opposition and our Party in government. Senator Baume laid out a principle of total freedom of choice with no regard to cost constraints, existing planning provisions and so forth. That is not a position that we support. We are willing to fund freedom of choice and any examination of the records would demonstrate that we do that very extensively, but we also believe, as a government in charge of scarce public resources, that a point must come beyond which choices cannot simply continue to be funded. The logical extension of a totally libertarian position is that the same group of parents could ask every year for new funds to start yet another new school. In a totally unrestricted world that might be possible; but in a world where existing schools can be badly affected and, therefore, the choices of those children and their parents badly affected by the proliferation of schools in their areas, and where the government must account for the expenditure of public funds and has many demands on the public purse, we simply do not accept that the basic position should be that, wherever the parents choose to go, and no matter how many times they choose to change and start something new, public funding ought to be forthcoming. Public funding is forthcoming, very generously, and it enables a huge diversity in this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Having had the opportunity of examining other school systems throughout the world, I believe that Australia has more publicly funded diversity in schools than any other country. I think that is a good thing but it is not a policy which can prevail without any recognition of the need to plan and the need to make responsible choices about the allocation of public funds. So I appreciate Senator Peter Baume's clarity in explaining the philosophy which has led him to put forward the amendments. They are unacceptable to us for the reasons that I have given and I reject them at this stage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I indicate that the Australian Democrats will not be supporting these amendments. The thing which is of interest to me is that Senator Peter Baume has moved them. I remember two parliaments ago, when Senator Baume was the Minister for Education and I was complaining about a shortfall in the funding of a particular part of education, Senator Baume telling me that there was not a limitless purse. He knew that when he was Minister and I think he knows it now. A dollar that is removed from one area within the total education cake is a dollar which is unable to be provided in another area.

SPEECH.PARA: What does this mean under a policy which says that if a group of parents gain certification that their school meets the basic requirements within a State that school should be registered? We all know that, unfortunately, those registrations vary enormously from State to State and that the education Ministers are working towards an agreement to try to get a more uniform basic set of rules with regard to registration. We already know that the rules are still fairly diverse throughout Australia. But upon a school gaining that basic minimum, the Department of Education is committed in its budget to supporting that school. That means that it is not possible for the Minister or the Department to have any regard to their primary role of funding because they must respond to those types of initiatives.

This also raises a question concerning Australian schools that have been established. Any school, no matter how small, is a costly venture. A school can be established, it can go on for one or two years and it can then collapse. That money has gone from the public purse, it has gone from education and it has been wasted. Members of Senator Peter Baume's Party have been talking about the fact that we must face up to our obligations in the economic world, the fact that we must face up to a whole range of things, and the possibility that we have been living beyond our means. I hardly think that these amendments fit in with that type of approach. At some stage or another we have to recognise that when we run a dual system there are additional costs. The community has said that it is willing to bear those costs. Fine. We all acknowledge that the dual system has those costs in it and that we are paying more for education than we would if we had a single system. I believe that the Australian community has indicated quite clearly that it desires a dual system. If that is the case we have to be careful that we operate that system in a way which is reasonable and effective for all concerned.

The original proposals in the Connors report are not dissimilar to those which are used by the systemic school systems themselves to make their decisions about where they will place their schools because they also have to meet a very rigid budget constraint. Everybody is hemmed in by this and I do not think the objections are really reasonable. I remember Senator Peter Baume, when Minister for Education, quite specifically looking at ways and means by which some type of cap could be put on the proliferation of schools. In fact, a number of proposals were floating around at that stage which I admit never came to fruition. However, I believe there were discussions at that stage to try to achieve some of the results that we are now discussing.

I believe that what we have before us is a compromise. Certainly it does not meet everything that everybody would want. But at least it says that if there is a Catholic school established another school will not be established straight off down the road without any respect for what that Catholic school is doing. Students will not suddenly be drawn away from that Catholic school. We are all very much aware that Catholic schools often take in other than Catholic students. Let us say that an Anglican school suddenly materialised in the next street. Such a move could destabilise a small school; it could cause it problems. I think the criteria that are set down in the legislation are not only directed at public schools; they are directed at all schools. The legislation seeks to ensure that there is some sort of predictability.

I have expressed the view of my party that we believe that the state system requires a shake-up and ought to be much more flexible than it is. We also believe that it ought to give expression to a much greater diversity than it currently does.

TALK.START.PARA: —Especially in your State.

—Especially in my State. That is a long term goal which can be achieved only by State governments. I think when one looks at some of the innovations that have been taking place in the state systems one sees that this type of thing is starting to occur. There is a recognition that there is a demand for diversity of schooling, that there is a demand for specialisation and a concentration on the particular talents that children have. In my State centres are being set up in state schools for artistically talented children. This is something that would not have occurred three or four years ago. It is occurring now in state schools and I believe this is something to be welcomed.

SPEECH.PARA: We are hoping that many of the aspirations of students can be fulfilled within the state school system. I hope that these types of developments will lead private schools and state schools working basically much along the same lines. But until that happens, the problem of damage that can occur as a result of proliferation is such that both private schools and state schools will be well served by a steady, predictable growth in both the public school sector and the private school sector. We can see that growth in terms of the schools which have been established already this year. Hopefully, that growth will continue in a reasonable way. I think probably all we can ultimately ask of any policy is that it fulfils a basic approach, that everyone knows the criteria on which they can make their applications and, hopefully, based on those criteria, that judgments made are just and equitable to all.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In advocating the omission of some parts of clauses 7 and 9 the Opposition does not advocate an unrestrained expenditure or, in the words of Senator Macklin, a limitless purse. I think the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) rightly summed up and responded to Senator Peter Baume's clear definition of the Opposition's approach. The Liberal Party of Australia and the Australian Labor Party have differences of approach. I will not bore the Committee by adding to that very well understood difference that has been summed up tonight by Senator Peter Baume and the Minister. I just wish to say that our approach, whilst giving greater freedom for schools to emerge in the community, to express parents' choice, is not to give an unrestrained approach, which were Senator Ryan's words, or a limitless purse. which were Senator Macklin's words. It cannot be denied by anyone that, when a student enrolled in a government school leaves to go to a non-government school, the recurrent funding in respect of that student is less costly to the taxpayer.

SPEECH.PARA: In terms of capital provision, there may be a submission from such a group of students for the formation of a new school, but that is governed again not by a limitless purse but by a budgeted capital provision each year for new schools. We do not wish to overthrow that; we are just complaining that this Government has cut the capital provision by $20m. In seeking the omission of those proposed new sections, we are not being irresponsible. We are recognising that there is a limit to taxpayers' money but that, in respect of any one student moving from the government sector, where the taxpayer funds 100 per cent of the cost of the government school place, to the non-government sector, which is funded by less than 100 per cent-as low as 12 per cent-from the Commonwealth, there is less recurrent call on the taxpayer.

Two questions arise from page 11 of the Bill. In proposed new sub-section (5), the Minister is unable provisionally to approve a proposed change to a school if there is a significant increase in or alteration to the school's clientele. I ask the Minister: What is an example of a significant increase and what is an example of a significant alteration to a school's clientele?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Examples of significant increases are set out in the administrative guidelines which are made available to schools. A significant increase would be, for example, a 10 per cent increase. There is some flexibility in the administrative guidelines. Perhaps Senator Teague should address himself to those guidelines. I must correct a couple of things Senator Teague said in his preamble to those questions. He has said several times in the course of this debate that the Government has cut the non-government schools capital program by $20m. In fact that is not right. There has been no reduction in the general capital funding for government or non-government schools. The amounts have been maintained in real terms.

SPEECH.PARA: The decision that was made in May was to discontinue the libraries element of the capital program. That represented $5m for the non-government school sector. The reason for that was that that program was set up in order to assist schools to upgrade their libraries. The Government was advised that this had substantially been done-that libraries in government and non-government schools throughout Australia had been substantially upgraded-and that the justification for that special element was no longer as strong. That is not to say that use could not have been made of the money, but the original intention was that there be an upgrading of the libraries, and that has substantially been achieved. The actual amount for normal capital projects has been maintained in real terms in every year of this Government's operation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to raise the question of Radford College and the continuation of its program to include years 11 and 12. I am sure that the Minister for Education in particular and honourable senators will recall that there has been a fairly troubled history to Radford College, which opened with years 7 and 8 in 1984 and has grown since then. Its intention is to proceed with year 11 in 1987. I am wondering whether the decision has been made as to whether the funding will be extended for this purpose, as it is fairly necessary for the school to get on with its arrangements to be able to open in 1987 and accommodate its year 11 students at that time.

—The application from Radford College to expand to years 11 and 12 is being treated in exactly the same fashion as every other similar application throughout the country. A new schools committee has been set up locally and has met to consider new applications, of which Radford's is one. I understand that at this stage it has not made a recommendation with regard to Radford. I think there are several others awaiting recommendations. When the local committee does make its recommendation to the Commonwealth Schools Commission, those recommendations will go to the Commission along with recommendations from State committees throughout Australia. Advice will come to me from the Commission in about January next year. Decisions will be made then. So Radford is in exactly the same position as every other non-government school throughout Australia seeking a similar expansion. It will receive its decision at the same time as all others-in January 1986.

—I have two questions. Firstly, I refer to the phrase `recognised by the State Education Minister'. Does that mean registered or does it mean something in addition to registered? Secondly, on page 12 of the Bill, schools are required to have a minimum acceptable number of students for a level of schooling. In the administrative guidelines which have been referred to by the Minister are those minimum acceptable levels set out for every year from kindergarten to year 12?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the first question is yes. Recognition means registration by the State education authorities. In regard to the second question, the minimum enrolment guidelines are actually set out in the Commonwealth of Australia Gazette. I point out to Senator Teague that those minimum enrolment guidelines were endorsed by the Australian Education Council and ought to be now a requirement in each State for achieving State registration. I am not sure that they are being applied quite precisely in every State, but they were endorsed in general by all State education Ministers.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Peter Baume's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 8 and 10 to 26-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 27 and 28-by leave-taken together.

TALK.START.PARA: —There are no actual amendments to the two clauses, but I indicate that the Opposition opposes them. They are part of the package of arrangements about which the Committee has been speaking. The reasons that we opposed proposed new sections 6A and 6B and 7A and 7B are the same reasons we will oppose clauses 27 and 28.

—The reasons for our opposing these clauses should be fully understood from our earlier remarks. I have one questions to ask the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan). Is it the case that nothing in any current legislation would limit a per capita grant being allocated to every student enrolled in a non-government school, whereas, for the first time, clause 27 and likewise clause 28, will introduce a completely new factor?

—As I explained to the Committee at an earlier stage, if a school has the procedures to seek approval to a maximum enrolment and goes beyond the approved enrolment and is not able to get approval for the extra students it would be in that position; but as far as we know, no schools are intending to do that.

—My point is that that is a new procedure. I understand what the Minister has just said, but at the moment, it is not possible to limit per capita grants for any school to the maximum enrolment; rather, all students enrolled do receive the per capita grant. These clauses bring in a new limit that creates what I have called a thirteenth category in the levels of funding for per capita grants to non-government schools. That means that some students now will get a zero recurrent fund.

—I am advised that there are no schools which have enrolled students beyond their approved limits. If they did that and were unable to gain approval subsequently they would not attract the per capita grant for those extra enrolled students. To this point, that has not occurred.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already stated the reasons for the Australian Democrats not supporting the amendments moved by the Opposition to clauses 7 and 9. For the record I state that on the basis of those reasons, we will also be supporting clauses 27 and 28.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses agreed to.
Remainder of Bill-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985, Commonwealth Education Institutions (Overseas Students) Amendment Bill 1985 and States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill (No.2) 1985-by leave-taken as a whole, and agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: STATES GRANTS (NURSE EDUCATION TRANSFER ASSISTANCE) BILL 1985STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1985

PROCTEXT.PARA: Consideration resumed from 29 November, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a second time.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a second time.
The Bills.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to raise the question of the nurses course which is being introduced at the Canberra College of Advanced Education to commence, I am glad to say, in 1986. It is a course that seems to have been thought through and planned most carefully. I think it answers the concerns that many people have as to whether under this system nurses will still be caring for people or whether they will merely be academics. The course, over three years, will comprise some 1,500 hours of educational training, most likely at the college for most of that time, but in addition there will be some 1,200 hours when the students will be in hospitals or in the place of community nurses, out and about learning the sorts of skills that most people would expect that nurses should have. It is certainly my hope that it works out well. I wonder whether the course which has been prepared has been accredited as a degree course. Can the Minister for Education (Senator Ryan) tell us whether that has been announced and conveyed to the college?

—The accreditation for the course described by Senator Reid has not been finally approved yet. There was an application from the Canberra College of Advanced Education to have a degree level course approved. However, the decision of the Australian Education Council, which has the responsibility for the development of college based nurse education, is that the undergraduate courses in nursing be diploma courses, and the CCAE course will be accredited as a diploma course. That process has not been completed yet.
—Can the Minister tell us how many other courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education are diploma courses?

—There would be a number of courses that are diploma courses and there are also degree courses. The particular question is the level of accreditation to be afforded to basic nurse training. The Australian Education Council has decided collectively that basic nurse training will be at diploma level.

—I wonder whether we can be told what criteria the Australian Education Council has taken into account in coming to that extraordinary decision, having gone to the trouble to take nurses out of hospitals to give them tertiary training. The Canberra College of Advanced Education is a very well respected, competent institution. This course has a very high science component-the same science subjects that are taught in the other degree courses at the college. Why is this nurse training course being downgraded to the status of a diploma course? What is the point of it all if they cannot do better than that?

—I think Senator Reid has misunderstood the nature of the new development. There has been no downgrading. It was in the State of New South Wales that basic nurse education in colleges began on a large scale. That State introduced it at diploma level in 14 colleges. Since that time all of the State authorities have agreed that that is the level at which college based nurse education will be taught and no State has departed from this. I am sure that Senator Reid will agree that it is very important as far as possible to have a uniform level of training so that nurses can have mobility between State and Territory hospitals. As far as I am aware there has been no criticism of this from the Royal Australian Nursing Federation or the other bodies representing nurses. I think it would be quite wrong to interpret this as a downgrading since clearly the move to college based basic training is regarded by the nurses themselves as an upgrading of their professional status and cerainly the Government regards it as such.

—I wonder whether the Minister could get a list of the courses at the Canberra College of Advanced Education which are still diploma courses so that we can have some idea of the way in which the Government regards the nurse training course, so we have some comparison between the courses which are regarded as diploma courses and those which are regarded as degree courses. I ask for this course to be re-examined in the light of the subjects that it contains, which come from the science faculties at the college. I also ask her to tell me why it is that the same subjects being taught in one area as in another are accredited to a degree course in the one case but only to a diploma course in the other.

—I am happy to provide that information to Senator Reid. I simply repeat that what is being developed here is a national system of college based basic nurse training. It is a system that has been developed by the States themselves and by the State institutions for colleges, with a very high degree of consultation with nursing organisations. I think it would be inappropriate to compare particular basic nurse training courses at the CCAE with other courses there. After all, we do not wish the CCAE to be an island. It is part of a system in which nurses will be trained to work in Australian health services generally. If Senator Reid would discuss this matter with nursing organisations I am sure she would find that they are entirely supportive of this development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The two Bills before us deal with nurse education. I place on record the Australian Democrats support for the Government's move in this area and our support of the State government initiatives in the co-operative development of college based nurse education which we, as a party, have always supported. I believe it is long overdue. Some of the comments made in the House of Representatives on this debate I think show an appalling lack of understanding of what is going on. I am thankful that at least in this chamber it is possible to have a more detailed debate and a more balanced representation of the views that exist in the community about nurse education.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 27 November, on motion by Senator Grimes:
That the Bills be now read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to take advantage of the first reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985 and allied Bills to mention matters which are not relevant to the Bills, something we are allowed to do on the first reading of this type of Bill. Last Saturday Mr Wallace Brown in the Courier-Mail expressed the opinion that any proposal to use Federal legislation to override the Queensland electoral redistribution was all rhetoric and little else. He also said in relation to the Premier of Queensland, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen:

SPEECH.PARA: The Premier can also rest easy about Canberra on the issue, and he knows that. It doesn't have the guts.

I have known Mr Brown for a long time and I have such a high respect for him as a journalist that I do not intend to argue with him publicly. Time will tell whether the rhetoric over the gerrymander is indeed all rhetoric and little else. Time will also tell whether Mr Brown's assessment that Canberra-I presume he means the Hawke Labor Government-does not have the guts, to use his words, to tackle this denial of electoral justice in Queensland is correct. In 12 months time it will be interesting to look back to see whether Mr Brown was correct. I certainly hope that by then he has been proved to be incorrect.

There seems little, if any, prospect that anything can be done about the Queensland gerrymander before the next State election. However, the new electoral boundaries are so obscene that we must look forward to the election after the next one. We must make sure that that election is fought on fair boundaries. I have made my position clear on the need for Federal legislation. No Australian government can stand back and allow a significant number of citizens in any State to have second class voting rights. I will press for and I will expect this Parliament to pass legislation to embody one vote one value as a basic principle of parliamentary electoral systems in Australia.

On a previous occasion I provided an analysis of the 1985 State redistribution in Queensland. That appears in the Hansard of 14 November 1985 at pages 2154 to 2157. This evening, however, I shall again outline why the system in Queensland is unacceptable. The 1985 Electoral Districts Act is the basis of the latest gerrymander of Queensland's electoral boundaries. This Act establishes a total of 89 electorates in four electoral zones. This is an increase of seven seats over the existing 82 seats in the Legislative Assembly. The most populous of these four zones is the south-eastern zone. This has 51 seats with an electorate quota of 19,357 voters. It is based on Brisbane, the Gold Coast, the Sunshine Coast, Ipswich, Toowoomba and adjoining regions. The next most populous zone is the provincial city zone. This has 13 seats and an electorate quota of 18,149 voters. This zone is based on Bundaberg, central Queensland, Mackay, Townsville and Cairns. The third zone is the country zone. It has 17 seats and an electorate quota of 13,131 voters. This zone is base on the rural hinterland of coastal provincial centres running in a narrow belt from north Queensland to the Brisbane valley. The zone with the least population is the western and far northern zone. This has eight seats and an electorate quota of 9,386 voters. It comprises the remainder of the State.

I defined the term `gerrymander' in a previous speech to this chamber. The particular gerrymander which has resulted in the latest redistribution in Queensland is the manipulation of State electoral boundaries to the political advantage of the National Party. Based on previous State election results, the National Party has used the redistribution to give itself a head start. Even if the majority of Queensland voters want the National Party thrown out of office, this task would not seem to be achievable unless there is a shift in voting patterns. I believe that such a shift is possible, but why should any party be allowed to manipulate boundaries to try to keep itself in power in spite of any desire of the electorate to the contrary?

The whole concept of the right to vote hinges on the equality of citizens' votes. Parliamentary democracy is based on the principle of equal voting rights for all people. In failing to uphold this principle, a National Party government is guilty of electoral cheating. It is not as if sound electoral principles have not been discussed previously. The United Nations Universal Declaration of Human Rights, for example, states:

The will of the people shall be the basis of the authority of government. This will shall be expressed in periodic and genuine elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage and shall be held by secret vote, or by equivalent free voting procedures.
The International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights states:

Every citizen shall have the right and the opportunity . . . to vote and be elected at genuine periodic elections which shall be by universal and equal suffrage, and shall be held by secret ballot, guaranteeing the free expression of the will of the electors.
Finally, Mr Justice Warren of the United States Supreme Court had this to say in 1969 on the subject of gerrymanders:

Legislators represent people, not trees nor acres. Legislators are elected by voters, not farms or cities or economic interests. To the extent that a citizen's right to vote is debased, he is that much less a citizen. The basic principle of representative government remains and must remain unchanged. The weight of a citizen's vote cannot be made to depend on where he lives.

The National Party has advanced two justifications for its gerrymander. These are that the recent redistribution provides for balanced representation and that it incorporates the principle of electoral weightage to benefit residents in far flung parts of the State. Let us examine both these attempted justifications. The argument of balanced representation does not stand up to scrutiny. It represents an admission by the National Party that under an electoral system not rigged in its favour it would practise discrimination against residents of non-metropolitan areas of Queensland. The gerrymander has not contributed one iota to decentralisation in Queensland. To the contrary, the National Party State Government, which has been in office since 1957, is yet to implement a decentralisation policy. This absence of policy has been verified in a report commissioned by the Government itself. The 1984 report on decentralisation, undertaken by Professor C. P. Harris of the James Cook University for the Department of Commercial and Industrial Development, stated:
The Queensland Government has no explicit decentralisation policy or set of policy measures to favour the establishment or expansion of industries in non-metropolitan parts of the State.

The gerrymander has not created any new jobs, investment or development in Queensland. It has not stopped the drift of population from the country to the cities. It has not arrested the declining per capita income in country areas. It has not led to the National Party State Government, which supposedly represents rural interests, contributing one cent towards the joint Federal-State assistance package to the sugar industry. The gerrymander is designed solely to preserve the National Party in government. I mentioned earlier that the National Party attempts to justify the gerrymander on the grounds of giving greater representation to the far flung parts of the State. In reality, electorates which are the greatest distance from Brisbane and those which are the largest geographically are given no significant advantage under the gerrymander. What has resulted is that Labor and Liberal votes are bottled up in zones with high quotas, while a predominance of National Party seats are found in the two zones with the small quotas. The very existence of the country zone, based on areas only a few hours drive from the State's major population centres, refutes the National Party's arguments about the need for electoral weightage.

I would like to outline a few examples of the anomalies and inequities that abound under the National Party's latest gerrymander. A person's vote in Winton or Longreach is worth 50 per cent more than a person's vote in Mount Isa. Winton and Longreach are in the electorate of Gregory, with 8,347 electors. The city of Mount Isa is in the Mount Isa electorate, with 12,678 electors. Both seats are in the western and far northern zone. A voter in the central Queensland mining town of Moranbah is a constituent of the Bowen electorate, a country zone seat with 12,275 electors. Just under 100 kilometres away by air or about 120 kilometres by road, a voter in the central Queensland mining town of Blair Athol is a constituent of the Peak Downs electorate, a western and far northern zone seat with 8,362 electors. A resident of Nanango is one of Deputy Premier, Bill Gunn's 19,152 constituents in the south eastern zone seat of Somerset. Drive 24 kilometres up the road to Kingaroy and meet some of the 12,865 voters in the Premier's country zone seat of Barambah. In other words, it has 19,152 voters as opposed to 12,865 only 24 kilometres away. Chinchilla on the Darling Downs is in the country zone seat of Condamine, which has 12,236 voters. Less than 50 kilometres away by road, the neighbouring town of Miles is part of the western and far northern zone seat of Roma, with 8,304 electors. Again, there are 12,236 voters as opposed to 8,304 voters with only 50 kilometres between the two.

The electorate with the highest quota of voters is Townsville East-1,570 kilometres from Brisbane-yet distance from the State's capital is meant to be one of the justifications for having seats with small enrolments. The electorate of Warrego stretches from the South Australian border to Springsure in Central Queensland. That is like having a resident of Ipswich in the same electorate as a resident of Mackay. The Warrego boundary conveniently skirts the Labor voting town of Cunnamulla, which is now lumped incongruously in the safe National Party seat of Balonne. The Aboriginal settlement of Wujal Wujal is completely surrounded by the electorate of Barron River, held by the National Party. But Wujal Wujal itself is deemed to be part of the Cook electorate, held for the Labor Party by Bob Scott. It is a land-locked island that exists in the provincial cities zone, but has been drawn as part of the western and far northern zone. For the record, the seat with the fewest voters is Balonne, with 8,162 voters. It is about a four-hour drive from Brisbane. However Townsville East has the most voters, with 20,837.

The National Party State Government's gerrymander is an indefensible denial of Queenslanders' most fundamental democratic right-the equality of their votes. The Labor Party will not relent or retreat in its campaign to bring about electoral justice in Queensland. Whilst the Labor Party in Queensland will be educating the public about this grossly distorted electoral system, I hold that the Federal Government should take legislative steps to safeguard the electoral rights of the citizens of Queensland.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Missen Sen A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak in this debate on a matter which likewise is not connected with subject matter of the legislation but concerns a matter which happened today, namely, the tabling of a report on a code of conduct for Australian companies operating in South Africa. This is a matter which has quite a long history in this Parliament. I think it is time that we realised what is being done in relation to it. Honourable senators will recall that on 18 April 1985 the Foreign Minister, the Hon. Bill Hayden, put down an Australian Code of Conduct for Companies with Commercial Interests in South Africa which was understood by all to be near enough to a final document, but subject to some discussion with companies. In the course of the Foreign Minister's speech in setting down that document Mr Hayden said, among other things:

SPEECH.PARA: The code incorporates, in its reporting format, a requirement for companies adhering to it to report annually to the Australian Government on their compliance, which will be monitored. The codes requirements related to all non-white employees of Australian companies with operations in South Africa reflecting the Government's concern about discrimination against all non-white people, of whatever racial or ethnic background. Its provisions are based on widely accepted international and domestic principles and are consistent with the basic human conventions of the International Labour Organisation and Australia's Racial Discrimination Act.
It may be said that generally the Code as then put down did comply in that way. Further, Mr Hayden pointed out:

The Code does not require companies to take action outside what can reasonably be considered normal commercial activities or industrial relations practices, nor are companies expected to breach South African Laws. For these reasons the Government expects and hopes that the maximum number of companies would agree to adhere to the Code.

That being a reasonable document, one would have expected it to remain substantially in place. There was no suggestion that it was to be substantially bowdlerised by further discussions with Australian companies. In detail the Minister set out the provisions of the Code. He said:

As the Code will be a voluntary undertaking it is desirable that there be consultations with relevant Australian interest groups, prior to the Code's finalisation, in order to obtain maximum domestic support for it.
He then said:
Following the consultative process the Code will be widely publicised and I shall issue both general and individual invitations to Australian companies to adhere to it.

What has happened is that it has not been widely publicised. It was sneaked into the House of Representatives at the end of last week, and has now been put in among a group of documents this morning which have not even been debated. One sees that it has been substantially changed in the meanwhile, substantially vitiating the importance of that document.

Some little time after putting down this Code, an article appeared in the Australian by Alan Fewster headed `Government bows on Code for South Africa'. This was mentioned in my speech on the adjournment on 9 October 1985 at page 943, and I do not propose to repeat what is said there, save to say that practically all that was said in that article has come to pass and has now been excluded from or changed in the Code of Conduct. Yet when I put this document down and expressed concern the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who I am pleased to see in the chamber, offered me the embargoed use of the Code and alterations and said I would then be able to see what was in it. I was unwilling to do that because a term of the engagement was that I was not to use it. A little later when Senator Vanstone sought also a concession on the same terms, she was refused by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) any possession of the amended Code. So at that stage we did not know what alterations had been made to the Code. I wish to draw attention to other things Senator Gareth Evans said in reply to my speech on the adjournment. He said:

It is regrettable that Senator Missen should have chosen to foist his indignation on us tonight, following the story in the Australian this morning because there is no foundation for either; that is to say, there is no justification for Senator Missen's indignation because there is no justification for the terms of the Australian story, with its heading `Government bows on code for South Africa'.
That has turned out to be entirely untrue. One must read what appears in the Code of Conduct to see those things that were thought to have been deletions from the Code--

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the rest of my very long reply on 9 October explaining why it was that it was not a watering down.

—I read the rest of the Minister's reply. The only thing that I can see different in the new Code is the provision that there is to be a person who is to be the commissioner or the person to investigate. Apart from that, all the things that were put in the article are correct. Senator Evans goes on to say:

SPEECH.PARA: I am advised that the Code, which is still in draft form and is the subject of discussions with business and trade union representatives, most certainly has not been watered down in the manner suggested in the article.

I will give chapter and verse to show that it has indeed been watered down, as the article said. If one compares the article with what is in the Code, one sees that this is so. In addition, the new Code, the altered Code, has come forward. A statement dated 29 November 1985 by the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Hon. Bill Hayden, sets out in glowing tems what the Code is doing. The statement does not refer to the alterations that are made to it but it does say, at page 2:

Speculation that the Code has been watered down is without foundation and is quite wrong. Indeed, the most significant change has been the introduction of an impartial and independent Administrator to monitor the Code.

I might say that that is the only alteration I can find whatsoever, not just the most significant. In fact, there were provisions in the Code before that it be monitored. Companies were required to answer questionnaires, to give details, and now that is all to be eliminated from the Code. Let me go quickly through what appears in the present Code and what is to be deleted. I will not refer to the article, which also sets that out. Under the heading of `Desegregation at places of work', we see the following expression in the new Code:
Except where the law of South Africa otherwise requires, companies should integrate the workplace, canteen, recreational, educational, training and other company-provided facilities.
That is what the present Code says. I do not know what it means. In the draft document first tabled, we find:
Except where the law of South Africa otherwise requires, companies should abolish the practice of segregation, which is a particularly offensive form of racial discrimination . . .

That has been cut out altogether by this new superficial provision. In regard to what companies will do in training and management there has been a considerable deletion from the draft Code. For instance we find in that draft Code the provision that companies should deal equally with all employees:

. . . companies should appoint and promote personnel solely on the basis of their qualifications and ability. To implement this provision fully the educational disadvantages of non-white employees may need to be compensated for.
That has gone from the new Code. Then it is stated:
To this end company training and development programs should be implemented to facilitate the employment of non-whites at all levels of the company.

That has gone from the Code; it is no longer to be found anywhere in it. So there has been a considerable displacement of requirements in that respect. A great many deletions from the draft Code will be effected in relation to labour restrictions. In particular, companies will be required to assist non-white employees to achieve and safeguard their basic rights. It was stated originally in the draft Code:
. . . employers should provide advice and or aid relating to legal matters . . . .
That has gone. Aid is not necessarily to be provided. It said also:
Because it denies non-whites freedom of movement and freedom of choice in employment, the system of migrant labour creates inequitable hardships for non-whites and their families.

Surely that is a truism, at the very least. That has gone from the Code. We find a real deletion when we come to the expression of quality of life. A substantial amount has gone from that. We see a cutting down of the provisions which were designed to help the people who work for Australian companies gain a greater living environment than they had. Companies had social as well as commercial responsibilities in these circumstances, but they have gone. The draft Code goes on:
Australian companies therefore should concern themselves with the quality of life of their employees and their families.

That also has gone. The draft Code then sets out a series of matters which should be considered. The provision that companies should be able to provide fringe benefits equally to all workers and, if not already available to non-white employees, should seek to introduce them has gone. Then there is a whole clause (b) which runs into something like three-quarters of a page. I summarise the points raised: Companies might assist in the housing of employees, the promotion of the welfare of the employees' families, the transport of employees, the provision of leisure and health service facilities, the provision of library and educational facilities, and the provision of subsidised nutritious meals to lowly paid employees. That has all been absolutely deleted from the Code as it now stands. There is also a difference in the question of monitoring. There is to be a provision now for a person who will investigate these matters. That person is to be an independent and impartial administrator and the idea of a questionnaire has gone altogether.

Overall, the Code of Conduct that we now have bears no resemblance to the previous one. The Minister, in his statement, gave no idea why these vast changes were made, why people had not had the opportunity to discuss them, why it had been left entirely to business and why the Parliament did not have some foreknowledge of the changes before they were declared to be the code in existence. There are many people who say that a code of conduct is not very effective but surely this will be said even more so when it is seen that this Government has resiled entirely from the provisions of the original Code and now seeks to foist a new code on us. I think it is time that the people knew this, even though this change comes at the end of the parliamentary session. We need to draw the attention of the people to this change because it shows once again the false nature of the Government's promises.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to detain the Senate, given the state of our program. However, Senator Missen has leapt into the breach, taking advantage of the procedures and forms of this place in order to make the speech that he has just made on the first reading of the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1985 and cognate Bills. I simply wish to make it clear that the Government rejects absolutely-as I did in the adjournment debate in this place on 9 October-the claims that have been made by Senator Missen that the newly redrafted Code which has just been made public by the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) in the past few days represents any kind of watering down at all of the previous Code of Conduct. It has been very substantially redrafted and a great many of the deletions to which Senator Missen referred are simply changes that have been made in the course of redrafting in order to reshape, tighten up or more clearly express some of the concepts involved.

SPEECH.PARA: I will not take the time of the House now to go through the Code chapter and verse but, as an illustration of the kind of thing I am talking about, I refer to just one example. Senator Missen made much-as did the original article in the Australian on 9 October on which he relied so much-of the alleged removal of a provision in the original Code which said that companies should also take reasonable measures to assist in various matters and there followed a list which included housing of employees, promotion of welfare of employees' families, transport, the provision of leisure and so on. Senator Missen failed to mention that the new Code does not just talk in terms of reasonable measures to assist but actually makes provision for all those matters in the form of an encouragement to companies to actually set aside funds for those particular purposes. I refer to a paragraph on page 9 of the revised Code which says:

The Australian Government also encourages companies to participate in, and to set aside funds for, the development of programs which address transportation to and from work, health services, housing and education-especially for the dependants of employees.

Inevitably, the nature of this document is hortatory and encouraging in tone. It does not set a series of legal requirements or obligations upon companies. It cannot do so any more here than it can in South Africa itself. It cannot require companies to do things which they are not able to do under the terms of South African law. The essence of the arrangement is a voluntary agreement by companies to observe these particular standards and I can assure the Senate that the standards set out here are no less rigorous than was the case before and in fact in many instances they are even more rigorous. For example, companies are now required to actually support changes to South African laws which adversely affect their employees. That is something which I understand was not in the original Code.

Senator Missen has selectively picked and threaded his way through this document, drawing attention to language which he cannot find repeated in the same terms in the original Code and drawing conclusions from that which are simply not justified. This Government's credentials on matters to do with South Africa are, as I hardly need to repeat, impeccable. We have gone much further than even the Fraser Government went-much to Mr Howard's disgust-in creating, imposing and agreeing to impose economic sanctions on South Africa. Of course we are now participating in the international exercise under the auspices of the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting designed to encourage and in various other ways draw the South African Government towards a more civilised stance on this particular matter. We have not ruled out the possibility of substantially tougher measures in the future, should that appear on review in six months time to be the appropriate course to take. We find it offensive that Senator Missen should come into this chamber and endeavour to outmoralise the Government, as it were, on this issue. There is no foundation for that contribution and no foundation for that claim. I shall take an appropriate opportunity, I hope later in the week, if the time enables me, to give a more substantial and detailed reply to some of the other criticisms Senator Missen has made.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate the second reading speeches in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
TAXATION LAWS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1985
This Bill will amend the Taxation Laws in several ways.
It represents a start to the Government's Legislative Programme to give effect to the measures the Treasurer announced on 19 September for reform of the Australian Taxation system.

In that regard, amendments of the income tax law in this Bill will provide for undeducted exploration and development expenditure incurred by petroleum and general mining companies to be treated as transferable company group losses.

Other amendments will withdraw the rebate and deduction for Capital subscribed to petroleum and afforestation companies, and reduce the taxation concessions available for investments in Australian Films.

Another reform measure to be given effect by this Bill will ensure that owner-builders of larger domestic building projects commenced after 30 June 1986 make deductions of tax under the prescribed payments system from payments made after that date.
Together with two other Bills that I will introduce shortly, this Bill will also finalise the implementation of the Government's 1985-86 Taxation Budget Proposals.
One of the three Budget measures designed to assist the Horse Racing Industry-the provision of a more generous livestock valuation option for Horse Breeders-is contained in the Bill.
The Bill will remove the exemption from tax for payments to Students under the Tertiary Education Assistance Scheme and the Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme.

As part of the Budget proposal to align A.C.T. taxes more closely with those of the States, the Bill will provide for the imposition of A.C.T. Stamp Duty on Loan Securities and on Transfers of units in unit trusts.
Finally, there are two measures in the Bill unrelated to the Budget of Tax reform.
First, the Bill will give effect to the proposal-announced on 21 May 1985-to amend the income tax secrecy provisions to permit greater use of taxation information by a Royal Commission.
Secondly, the Bill will give the Force of Law in Australia to a new Comprehensive Taxation agreement and a related protocol with Finland that were signed in Canberra on 12 September 1984.
A number of Technical Amendments of the Taxation Laws are also to be made by the Bill.
Mr President, I now turn to outline in greater detail the more significant amendments contained in the Bill.
Petroleum and General Mining Company Losses

As announced in the Treasurer's Tax reform statement, an annual election is being made available to General Mining and Petroleum Companies to enable them to have undeducted exploration and development expenditure treated as transferable company group losses.
Under the Existing Law, the deduction allowable for such expenditure cannot create or increase a Mining or Petroleum Company's deductible carry-forward loss.
One result of this is that any such expenditure not offset aganist the company's income may not be transferred to another company in the same group under the group loss transfer arrangements.

Measures in the Bill will allow a Mining or Petroleum exploration company that is part of a company group to elect that any excess deductible exploration and development expenditure incurred in the 1985-86 and subsequent income years forms part of the company's carry-forward loss available for transfer to another company within the same group.
A separate election will be available for each year of income.
The Estimated Revenue cost of the measure is $70 million in 1986-87 and $65 million in 1987-88.
Capital Subscribed to Petroleum and Afforestation Companies

In giving effect to another tax reform proposal, provision in the Bill will withdraw the Tax Concessions in respect of moneys paid on shares in Petroleum or Afforestation Companies. First, there is the tax rebate of 27 cents in the dollar for moneys paid on shares in an eligible Petroleum Company. This is available where the Company lodges a declaration that it has expended, or will expend, the moneys on prospecting, Exploration or Mining for petroleum in Australia. There is also a deduction for one-third of calls paid on non-redeemable shares in a Company whose Principal Business is Afforestation in Australia, where the call moneys are for use in that Business.

Both the rebate and deduction are being withdrawn for moneys paid on shares after 19 September 1985, other than moneys paid by a person on calls made on or before that date on shares then owned or beneficially owned by the person. Withdrawal of these concessions is estimated to result in a gain to revenue of $10 million in 1986-87 and $15 million in 1987-88.
Investment in Australian Films

As the Treasurer announced on 19 September 1985 in the tax reform statement, the tax concessions for investment in the production of Australian films are to be reduced as part of the restructuring of assistance to the film industry. For eligible expenditure contracted for after 19 September, the special income tax deduction will be 120 per cent of the expenditure, in lieu of 133 per cent. The associated income tax exemption in respect of the net income from a film will be 20 per cent of the eligible investment, rather than 33 per cent. The higher concession levels will, however, continue to be available to an investor who takes up an interest in an Australian film in place of an underwriter who entered into underwriting arrangements on or before 19 September 1985. This reduction in taxation concessions is to be offset by additional funding of $2 million in 1985-86 and $3 million in each of the following two years. This will be achieved through the special production fund administered by the Australian Film Commission. The estimated net saving to revenue is $35 million in 1986-87 and subsequent years.
Prescribed Payments System

This Bill will also give effect to the tax reform measure to impose on ``owner-builders'' a liability under the prescribed payments system to make deductions of tax from prescribed payments made in connection with domestic construction projects exceeding $10,000 in cost. Mr President, this measure represents the Government's considered response to industry representations that an owner-builder should, as far as the prescribed payments system is concerned, be treated in the same way as the professional builder. By this Bill, owner-builders are to have the same obligations and duties as are currently imposed on professional builders under the prescribed payments system. This change will apply in relation to prescribed payments made by owner-builders on or after 1 July 1986 in connection with domestic construction projects costing more than $10,000 that are commenced on or after that date. It is estimated that this measure will lead to a net revenue gain of $16 million in 1986-87 and $4 million in 1987-88. Another amendment to be made to the prescribed payments system provisions of the law will overcome a possible technical weakness in the present statutory definition of a ``householder''. This amendment will affect neither the practical operation of, nor collections received under, the prescribed payments system. It will apply from the date of royal assent to the Bill. Mr President, as the Treasurer said to honourable members when delivering his statement on reform of the Australian taxation system on 19 September, the Government is engaged in a tax reform exercise, not a tax raising one. The gains to revenue arising from the tax reform changes will be applied by the Government towards substantially easing the burden of high marginal rates of tax on honest middle income taxpayers. Together with other elements of our tax reform package, these changes will restore fairness to the Australian tax system.
Live stock Valuation Option
