TALK.START.PARA: —We will take them in Rockhampton if you do not want them.

—If Senator Collard went to one of his local schools and said that there was a chance that they could have the kind of damage that occurred at the Ryan school, if he went to the pensioners and suggested to them that because of the noise factor they could be woken at different hours during the day when they are trying to catch up on a little sleep or if he were to say to the citizens of Rockhampton that there was a chance of either of these incidents over the city, I wonder whether he would have very much support. I think that it is completely irresponsible for a member of this Parliament to treat these two incidents in a frivolous manner.
—Not as irresponsible as going on with the drivel you are going on with.

—I see. The honourable senator thinks that the possibility of Mirage jets crashing on built-up areas in a city is drivel. I thank Senator Collard. I will make sure that the people of Rockhampton and Townsville take note of the honourable senator's comments. I would like to know where else in Australia such training exercises are carried out in such close proximity to a major city. I also want to know how the RAAF liaises with the Department of Aviation to ensure that there is a clear definition of priorities between civilian and defence use. What is the Department's policy on RAAF aerobatic exercises being conducted over a civilian airport when domestic flights are arriving? This is another aspect of the whole issue that happened last Friday, the day of the first incident. Is it appropriate for FA18 jets to perform low flying exercises over a civilian airport when two commercial aircraft are on the tarmac awaiting unloading procedures?

SPEECH.PARA: Why is one of only two runways at Townsville closed at the moment to allow for the parking of the visiting jets and to enable them to bomb up in readiness for training exercises? Is the one other runway adequate to cater for international, domestic and charter flights in all circumstances? Are traffic control operations adequately staffed and equipped and are staff members adequately trained to cope with the demands of those exercises which have started to occur at this level only over the last few weeks? Domestic flights have been delayed by up to 20 minutes by these exercises. Is that reasonable? To what extent are private charter flights rerouted to accommodate these exercises?

It could well be, as Senator Collard seems to think, that this is an unnecessary issue for the concern of the Senate, but I imagine that in the event of a major tragedy over a city in Australia Senator Collard would have rather a different view. I am not saying that either of these incidents would have necessarily resulted in a major tragedy, but the risk of something happening is there. This needs to be investigated and we need to be absolutely sure that there will never be an accident over a built-up area.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of the Senate to some matters relating to the Australian Taxation Office, particularly the matter of unpaid, uncollected tax from individual trusts and companies. The Senate might remember that when the previous Government was in office, many of the leading members of the then Opposition, who now curiously occupy responsible places in this Government, were saying the most irresponsible things about what this outstanding tax figure actually meant. I could quote, for example, the Minister for Trade (Mr Dawkins) who said that $2.7 billion in outstanding tax was, in fact, tax that was avoided as a result of the neglect of the former Government. The Commissioner of Taxation, of course, disagreed with that view. It did not discourage Mr Dawkins from continuing to say that. In fact, the tax has been identified as being outstanding because people had objected to, and refused to pay, the great bulk of that tax. If there had been successful avoidance and evasion arrangements the Taxation Commissioner would not have been aware of that tax being outstanding. It is a total distortion and an attempt to mislead the public.

SPEECH.PARA: The reason it is interesting to note that now is that the figure of $2.7 billion to which Mr Dawkins and others referred, has now grown to a record $3.2 billion. It has now, I stress, reached a record level and has increased by 17 per cent over the level that existed at a time when the Australian Labor Party was saying that the outstanding amount of tax was a disgrace and was evidence of indolence and incompetence by the then Government. I suppose that if Mr Dawkins were sitting in Opposition he would be able to say the same thing now, just as incoherently and incompetently and improperly as he said in opposition. I will concede that, in fact, as a proportion of outstanding tax the amount unpaid has diminished from last year's record level of 25.74 per cent to 22.5 per cent. Of course, this is because of the massive increase in tax raisings under the present Government. As the people of Australia know, this is the biggest taxing, biggest spending government in Australia's history. The taxing element is certainly to the fore now.

I would like to mention another matter which follows from this level of unpaid tax collections. I refer to the level of staff in the Australian Taxation Office. The recent report of the Commissioner of Taxation went into this matter and outlined in particular that there had been an increase in the staffing level in 1984-85 of about 727 people. The interesting thing is that included in that are 100 members of staff in the Taxation Office to assist temporarily in the collecting of outstanding tax. They are to go. Of course, next year the staffing level will be reduced by that number of people. However, it is interesting to see that the Taxation Office faces substantially increased tax burdens on its staff as a result of changes being made in the tax structure of which the Senate is particularly aware and which, in fact, it was discussing before the adjournment. As there will be an enormous increase in pressure of work imposed on the Taxation Office one would have thought that the Government would take some appropriate measures to assist the Taxation Office in handling the added burden which the Government will be giving it.

It is interesting to notice that this assumption would be supported by the May 1985 Forward Estimates, in which the number of people then expected to be in the Taxation Office in the 1986-87 financial year was 16,929. However, the latest Forward Estimates which came out in November have revised that figure downwards to 16,389, which is in fact a fall of exactly 100 from the current year's level. The May 1985 Forward Estimates showed that for 1987-88 the number of staff in the Taxation Office would rise to 17,469. This has now been revised down in the latest Forward Estimates to a constant figure of 16,389. That is a reduction of 1,080 from the Forward Estimates. In fact, that is a reduction of 6 per cent.

How on earth the Tax Office will handle the enormously increased burden it will face while in fact having to put up with a cut of 6 per cent in staff from original Forward Estimates intrigues me. I think the Senate would be justified in saying that it raises questions about the integrity of the Forward Estimates. There is no doubt that when we look at the enormous cost-benefit that emerges in the Tax Office-no doubt the Taxation Office will be arguing this case with some vigor-no doubt there will be strong arguments for increasing the capacity of the Tax Office to apply additional people these tasks.

I am not necessarily arguing that the Tax Office should be massively increased in size, largely because I think the reasons for the increase in size are unnecessary and unwarranted. I think that the great bulk of the tax changes now being introduced under the false term `reform' could be done without. The essential point is that either the Government is deluding itself or misleading this Parliament by saying in its Forward Estimates that in fact there will be no increase in numbers in the Taxation Office or it is misleading the Taxation Office or it does not know what on earth it is doing. Let us recognise that it already has volumes of staff problems in the Taxation Office. The annual report of the Commissioner of Taxation says on page 33:

Recruitment of large numbers of qualified and suitably experienced staff has proved to be difficult . . . resignations, retirements and the recent rapid expansion has depleted the levels of experience in the office. In recognition of this `experience gap', staff training methods were reviewed in detail during the year.
That is part of the problem the Australian Taxation Office faces. That the problem manifests itself is also clearly shown on page 54 of the annual report, where it says:
A particular problem that has been experienced concerns delays in the processing of income tax returns in which the prescribed payments system credit is claimed.
One of the factors involved is:
. . . a number of internal system deficiencies have thrown up discrepancies between the amount of credit claimed by taxpayers and the amount recorded as available in Tax Office records.

I suppose members of the public could say to the Taxation Office and to the Government: `It is just too bad if inadequate staffing levels mean that the Office does not collect the tax it should be collecting, but it goes a little far when inadequate staffing levels mean that people are not getting their rebates appropriately and adequately'.

I would like to make a few other brief remarks about the Taxation Office in these circumstances. It seems that lately some of its court cases have been going badly. The Taxation Office has had judgments in relation to the Sahhar case which, briefly outlined, mean that there was no need to pay penalties on incorrect returns in certain circumstances. There was a failure to succeed on matters relating to tax shelters. Certainly the Brayson Motors Pty. Ltd case was no help to the Commissioner in terms of sales tax. Nonetheless, there is one matter which is of major interest, and that is the Office's determination to proceed, as Mr Gyles the Special Prosecutor recommended, with section 260 prosecutions in relation to vendor-shareholders and bottom of the harbour matters. This will underline another matter on which the Australian Labor Party behaved most inappropriately in opposition and even more inappropriately in government. I refer to the claim that because of the previous Government's activities people who had been vendor-shareholders got away with multi-millions of dollars. The fact is that, if section 260 is alive and well, that money has the capacity to be sought, along with penalties.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under existing law.

—Under existing law; that is exactly the point. The Office is at present testing that. There are 27 vendor-shareholders who received assessments last September who have appealed against them. Those appeals have been received and obviously are going through the legal system. The essential element is that the allegations made by Labor when in opposition that the previous Government had failed to perform properly will be proved to be wrong by the use of existing law. All we were doing when in office was clearly defining, so that there could be no scope for confusion, what we believed the law should be. The fact is that the existing law was there; it was capable of various interpretations by various courts, but the law had been there for a long time. I am glad to see the Taxation Office doing what Mr Gyles recommended, something the Taxation Office itself had resisted with great vigour.

SPEECH.PARA: While on the subject of Mr Gyles, I hope that the Taxation Office, or whoever is involved in one of Mr Gyles's recommendations, is not dragging the chain on a matter of some significance. Mr Gyles noted in his final report, presented to this chamber on 20 March, that one of the matters he has drawn to the attention of the Director of Public Prosecutions concerns the possible implications of a small number of former tax officials in aspects of company stripping. I am glad to see that the Minister in the chamber is the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans), who represents the Attorney-General, because it would be appropriate if this Government gave the Senate an assurance that something was being done about this report of Mr Gyles. I must say that I have heard nothing further about the small number of former tax officials who were possibly implicated. The Government has to get off its tail and the Prosecutor has to act so that these people, who presumably are identifiable, are either cleared as quickly as possible or prosecuted as quickly as possible. This report, which covers the period to 21 September 1984-in other words, a period over a year ago-has not been able to encourage the Government or the prosecutor to tell us what on earth is happening. I hope that the Minister will take that on board and encourage the Prosecutor to proceed as quickly as possible with this matter.

In conclusion, it is interesting to see now that the Australian Taxation Office no longer lists at the end of its report defaulting taxpayers. The points made about it being a double penalty in many cases may be accurate; there is a case for and against listing these people. It is interesting to see that the Government has accepted this view of the Taxation Office, which seems to be in conflict with its previous view that people involved in bottom of the harbour schemes, including innocent vendor-shareholders, should have their names publicised. Only a year ago that was an essential part of the Government's previous legislation; yet here the Government is taking a totally contrary view. I am glad to see that experience in government has obviously demonstrated to the Australian Labor Party that most of what it has been saying about tax over the last five years has been utter bunkum.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last week I asked a question of Senator Grimes, the Minister representing the Minister for Health, about the nurses strike in Canberra. The Minister commented on the preamble to my question but he did not really deal with the substance of it-that is, what will happen to my constituents? I need to raise this matter again because the nurses strike has escalated since then. Only last Friday evening, I am led to believe, there was a strike at Canberra airport at 5 o'clock, in support of the nurses. That may have inconvenienced some people; it is a time which is quite busy at Canberra airport. In that sense, of course, only those who were able and fit were inconvenienced. The ones I am really concerned about are those who are sick. In this morning's newspaper we learned that the crisis had intensified as a result of the decision last night of the Royal Australian Nursing Federation to halve the staff that had been working in critical care areas.

SPEECH.PARA: What I really want to ask the Government is whether it is aware of the worsening crisis in Canberra due to the nurses strike. What contingency plans are there to provide this community with a health service? As an aside, I mention that we are all continuing to pay our Medicare levies but we really are not getting the universal coverage we have been promised. It is particularly the plight of those in nursing homes to which I wish to refer. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a Press release issued on 29 November 1985 by Dr Peter Sinnett, the Director of the Rehabilitation and Geriatric Service in the Australian Capital Territory.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
PRESS RELEASE
29 November 1985

Among the responsibilities of the Rehabilitation and Geriatric Service, is the care of 250 residents in Allambee and Jindalee Nursing Homes. These elderly people are among the most frail, the most disabled, and indeed the most defenceless members of the Canberra community. For them there is no alternative to Nursing Home accommodation.
Whatever the issues in the present dispute, it is the care of people, especially the frail elderly, that must remain the primary concern of the community.
A measure of a society's values is the care that it provides for its aged and handicapped people. Certainly, this group should not be exploited in a conflict between management and unions.

Ideally, the parties should have excluded the Nursing Homes from the present industrial dispute, the more so as at the time of the present strike there was no dispute existing between the Royal Australian Nursing Federation and the Rehabilitation and Geriatric Service in relation to staffing or any other issue. It was particularly disappointing therefore, to learn on Thursday 28 November 1985, that the Royal Australian Nursing Federation had withdrawn the Grade II Supervisory Staff from the homes. This action seriously reduced the nursing cover available at Allambee and Jindalee Nursing Homes, and therefore increased the risk to the residents. In addition, it placed an excessive burden on nursing staff who have continued to man the homes, as well as on the relatives of the residents who have been given support by the Council on the Ageing and the Salvation Army to provide care during this difficult period.
We pay tribute to the level of care that has been maintained through the dedication and commitment of staff, relatives and volunteers.

In order to provide an adequate level of care for the vulnerable elderly residents of our two nursing homes, we ask that nursing homes be excluded from the present dispute, or at least that the Grade II Supervisory and Charge Sisters be allowed to return to duty.
PETER SINNETT
Director
Rehabilitation and Geriatric Service
A.C.T. Health Authority

TALK.START.PARA: —Dr Sinnett refers to the 250 residents in the two nursing homes as `the most frail, the most disabled'. He asks that they be excluded from the strike and that normal nursing services continue. The other statement which I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard is a copy of a letter written by the Chairman of the Australian Capital Territory Council on the Ageing, Mrs Kath Bourke, to the Secretary of the Royal Australian Nursing Federation again seeking that nursing homes be excluded and that normal services return.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
3 December 1985
PRESS RELEASE
The following letter was delivered to the RANF today.
The Secretary
Royal Australian Nursing Federation (A.C.T.)
3 Lonsdale Street
Braddon, A.C.T. 2601
Dear Ms Power

I am writing on behalf of the A.C.T. Council on the Ageing to request that the Jindalee and Allambee Nursing Homes be excluded from the current industrial dispute between the RANF and the A.C.T. Health Authority.

Council has been reluctant to comment while the matter is before the Arbitration Commission, but our growing concern for the residents who are the real victims of the dispute compels us to appeal on their behalf.

It is regrettable that frail, elderly people who have no means of making their voices heard, many of whom cannot even feed themselves, are being denied the basic human right to appropriate care and attention.

This Council has over many years been the one community group which has actively pursued with the Minister for Health and the Capital Territory Health Commission (now the A.C.T. Health Authority), the issues of adequate accommodation and resources to provide appropriate care of the elderly.
We therefore appeal to your Federation on behalf of the 250 frail and dependent residents to exclude the two Nursing Homes from the current industrial action.
Yours sincerely
Mrs K. A. BOURKE
Chairman

TALK.START.PARA: —In her letter Mrs Bourke makes it plain that she does not want to get involved in any dispute, but she does make a plea for the frail elderly people who are in the nursing homes. I join in that plea. I felt myself that the nurses could have gone back to work last Wednesday after the Arbitration Commission hearing. Certainly at that time they had not won the things that they were seeking, but they had massive public support and support from doctors. They could have said: `We have not actually got extra staff yet, but there is to be a work evaluation of nursing services. We will go back and provide the service and we will rely on the public to see that the evaluation goes ahead and is honoured'. The nurses would not have won what they had been on strike for, but at least the services would have been resumed. Even now I ask that the nursing homes be attended in the normal way. I repeat my question to the Government: What contingency plans does it have, and is it making any attempt to negotiate with the Royal Australian Nursing Federation to resume normal nursing in the nursing homes?

SPEECH.PARA: We have had services in the nursing homes and the hospitals. In the nursing homes in particular the Salvation Army and members of the Council on the Ageing have been working and families have been giving support where they are able to do so. However, those who have been working there since the strike began are becoming rather jaded and they may not be able to keep it up for much longer. They are, of course, volunteers. In addition, there have been nurses working who are members of the Hospital Employees Federation but some of the nurses who have been provided by the RANF in the critical care areas have been cut back.

In addition and prior to this there were problems in the community health area. I needed to refer to that as well. The reason for that is that the community nurses made their points known in a letter that they sent to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett), the four local Federal members of the Parliament and the House of Assembly. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the letter written about the community health services.
Leave granted.
The letter read as follows-
Dear Sir,
As a Community Health Nurse in the A.C.T. I wish to inform you of the staffing situation currently causing great stress to me and my colleagues.
For example:
(i) No holiday relief has been available to our work area this year, with the result that each team member has had to carry an extra load of work to cover community needs.
(ii) There has been no sick relief within our area since March, adding further stress as a second workload is distributed amongst team members.

(iii) Children who have been screened and found with defects have not yet been channelled via the Child Health Medical Officer for appropriate action because of lack of staff, and many more children referred by teachers are still waiting to be seen. This situation has been particularly compounded as a result of the first two points.
Staff have for some time been manifesting physical as well as emotional signs of stress, and sick leave has in fact been accelerated.

Members of our teams are seriously contemplating resignation. There has been a high turn-over in Community Nursing staff because of these above-mentioned work stresses and the comparatively low pay for highly skilled and demanding work, when better salaries are available elsewhere. I, for one, have considered a change in occupation for this very reason.

I request your understanding and practical help in representing our cause to the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority, and the Minister for Health, Dr Blewett, in a manner that will evoke a positive outcome in as short a time as possible. None of us wished to see a continuation of the hardship which has been imposed upon many of our clients in recent months, if not years.
Your faithfully,
(Miss) Jill Clingan.
Copies to:
The Prime Minister, Mr Hawke
The Minister for Health, Dr Blewett
Senator Susan Ryan
Senator Margaret Reid
Ros Kelly, M. P.
Mr Jim Leedman, House of Assembly.

TALK.START.PARA: —The letter refers to there being no holiday relief and no sick leave relief available. It also refers to the stress that the nurses are working under and the high turnover in staff. Since the hospitals have virtually closed down, this situation has been heightened by the number of patients who are at home and are calling on the community health services they would not otherwise have done had they been in hospital. I and other local members are beginning to get phone calls from patients who would have been expecting surgery. I just mention one case. A man who has been expecting to undergo upper spinal surgery since last June has now been told that he is not likely to get it before next April. He is obliged to go to clinics regularly in order to receive pain killing injections and other treatment. Other patients are also becoming distressed. The nurses have a case. There is no doubt about that and this community believes in what they have to say. That is quite apparent. But there are consequences resulting from what has occurred. Again I ask the Government to attend to the questions that I have posed as to what will happen and what plans it has in mind.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collard Sen S.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLARD
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: — I am drawn into this adjournment debate briefly by the remarks made earlier by Senator Reynolds--
—We will forgive you.

—It is only the second time that I have spoken in the adjournment debate. Senator Reynolds raised a few of the problems associated with the joint user base at Garbutt in Townsville. I am drawn into the debate because I am concerned about the alarm that could be generated by such remarks in a forum such as this. I do not think that raising the alarm in the community, unnecessarily or otherwise, does any good. Townsville is not the only joint user base in Australia. Indeed, Fairbairn in Canberra is one, as are Darwin and the Mirages' home base of Williamtown. While Richmond is not a joint user base, the aircraft there come in and take off over built-up areas. So the problem, insofar as there is a problem, is not peculiar to Townsville. I think it reprehensible that we can build up unnecessary alarm in people's minds. If these people do not want the Royal Australian Air Force base-Senator Reynolds said that they do-they should remember that they cannot have their cake and eat it. Obviously, it is of great economic value to any community to have a base that size with exercises and transiting crews. If a community is going to have that and the economic benefits which flow from it, it has to live with the fact that, if the defence forces are to be any use at all, they have to train regularly.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the problems that I worry about is that, because of Budget restrictions, our defence forces do not train hard enough and often enough. If there is a problem, I would much rather it were dealt with a bit more judiciously and quietly than by raising unnecessary alarm in people's minds. Mention was made of bombs falling off aircraft. I guess that there would be more danger from a civilian airliner with full fuel tanks crashing into a built-up area than there would be from explosive bombs which are not armed falling from a military aircraft in a built-up area. The whole purpose of not arming bombs is that they will not explode in a situation such as this.

Let me deal now with low level operations over airports. Our F111s at Amberley are very close to a major population centre. They train all over the Lockyer Valley and the Darling Downs area using their terrain following radar at very low altitudes. We have an agreement with the United States of America in regard to the B-52 bombers. Admittedly, these aircraft fly over very sparsely populated areas but they train at very low altitudes at Cape York. I have travelled in one of those aircraft on a exercise such as this.

I do not think it does anybody any good if we raise unnecessary alarm in one city where our defence forces are training-they are not getting enough training overall-because this happens to be a joint user base. When the Garbutt Airport was first established I do not think there were any houses under the flight paths of these aircraft. There certainly are not any houses under the flight path over the common out towards the sea. There are houses inland and that is unfortunate but it is a case of caveat emptor. Those people built their houses well after the airport was established.

I end as I began. We cannot have our cake and eat it too. We have a Defence Force which has to train. It has to use bases where they are established. Nobody would suggest-in fairness, I do not think even Senator Reynolds suggested this-that we should spend a massive amount of money in building a base a bit further away and for the town to move towards it. We have very limited bombing ranges in this country and our defence forces have to use what sparse resources they have.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I noted what Senator Reynolds had to say on the activities of the Royal Australian Air Force over Townsville. I will, of course, refer her concerns to the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I am, no doubt, obliged also to refer Senator Collard's contribution on the same subject to the Minister for Defence but I do not think he will derive quite the same nourishment from it.

SPEECH.PARA: I think that probably is what can be said of Senator Michael Baume's contribution on the subject to taxation. I doubt whether the Treasurer (Mr Keating) will lose much sleep over Senator Baume's miscellaneous neuroses in this respect but, notwithstanding that, I will refer them to the Treasurer.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope you are going to be more gracious about the nursing strike.

—All right. Senator Reid made an admirable contribution to an ongoing debate of some considerable complexity, difficulty and sensitivity. Again, whether the Minister for Health (Dr Blewett) will regard it as admirably as I do, since she kept it so short, is something that remains to be seen. But I will at least ensure that he is aware of what Senator Reid has had to say.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 11.10 p.m.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many Australian delegates attended the Nairobi World Conference which marked the end of the United Nations Decade for Women.
(2) On what basis were the delegates to the Conference chosen.
(3) How many members of the delegation have previously attended Conferences and meetings held outside of Australia in relation to the United Nations Decade for Women.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Prime Minister has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (2) The Delegation was carefully chosen to provide the necessary range of backgrounds and skills essential for Australia to make the best possible contribution to the work of the Conference.
(3) 6 members of the Delegation attended preliminary Conferences, and all overseas based Delegates attended a number of local meetings.

(4) 3 Federal Senators and 1 Member of the Legislative Council of New South Wales, all of whom are members of the Australian Labor Party were members of the delegation; the political affiliations, if any, of other Delegates are not recorded.

Shand; 27 July-5 August; Geneva. Ms G. Pincus; 29 July-16 August; Geneva, Strasbourg, London. Ms J. Hamilton; 27 July-5 August; Nairobi, Bombay. Ms H. King; 27 July-4 August; Dar Es Salaam, Harare.
(9) Overall estimated cost is $119,580.

(10) $55,600 for 16 Australia based and 2 New York based Delegates, $2,350 for a Stenographer from Lisbon and $281 for an Administrative Officer on short term mission to Rome and Athens to be diverted to Nairobi. No allocation was made for spouses.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 7 November 1985:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many servicemen in each of the three services apply for the education allowance each year.
(2) How many applications are approved.
(3) What is the total number of servicemen currently receiving the allowance.
(4) How does this compare with the public service departments such as Foreign Affairs.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Defence has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Numbers vary from year to year depending upon posting circumstances. Service personnel posted overseas for long-term periods are eligible for Child Education Allowance; eligible Service personnel on long-term posting within Australia receive Education Allowance, generally restricted to the two years preceding a secondary school public examination or assessment. In certain cases, where circumstances justify, provision exists for payment over a longer period.
As a representative figure, numbers from 1985 are quoted. For this school year, 26 RAAF, 46 Army and 26 Navy personnel applied for either Child Education Allowance or Education Allowance.
(2) Of these, 26 RAAF, 41 Army and 26 Navy applications were approved.

(3) Allowing for carry over of some applications approved in previous years where personnel are still in receipt of the allowances, currently 67 RAAF, 41 Army and 23 Navy Service people receive one or other allowance. Three Navy personnel have ceased to be eligible during the year following either return to Australia or discharge from the Service.

(4) The Australian Public Service has identical provisions in respect of overseas service and similar provisions for service within Australia, but normally restricted to the last two years of secondary schooling.
Verbal inquiry of the Department of Foreign Affairs indicates that 89 of their personnel were receiving APS Child Education Allowance for the 1985 school year.

ANSWER.TO.QWN.TITLE: Forward Estimates of Income and Expenditure

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On 27 March 1985 (Hansard, page 876), Senator Chaney asked me the following question without notice:

ANSWER.PARA: In the light of the need for the community to understand the difficulties and the necessity for the restraint in government expenditure, will the Minister release the details of the forward estimates of income and expenditure for 1985-86, as the Government did for 1983-84?

When Senator Chaney asked this question, I indicated a tentative intention of releasing details of forward estimates of outlays in May, and on 9 May I made that release. I also undertook to seek the Treasurer's advice on that part of the question relating to the publication of the forward estimates of receipts. The Treasurer has provided the following information in answer to the honourable senator's question:

Forward estimates of receipts have been published on only one occasion-in 1983-84. Publication was necessary on that occasion to dispel misinformation distributed by the former Prime Minister and his Treasurer concerning the deficit in prospect for 1983-84. For electoral purposes the former Government stated that the prospective deficit was officially estimated at $6 billion and declined to disclose official advice that the deficit in prospect was in fact $9.6 billion.

The Government did not publish such Forward Estimates for 1984-85. The intervening twelve months have not changed the arguments that lead to the conclusion that Forward Estimates of receipts should not be published.

There are inherent uncertainties attached to the preliminary estimates of Budget receipts, relying as they do almost exclusively on forecasts of underlying economic parameters. The forecasts of these key parameters are themselves subject to great uncertainty.

In the period leading to the Budget, these forecasts are subject to very frequent revision in the light of actual receipt collection, new economic data and the continuing reassessment of the economic outlook.
The publication of such estimates could result in misleading signals being conveyed as to the Budget stance and to the future course of developments in the economy more generally.
Given these considerations, the Government does not believe that it is appropriate to publish the forward estimates of Budget receipts.
